Please add a new variable to CVS text label decorations that will allow to use the same label value as confugured in the repository properties. In many cases it will be better then using host name combinted with repository path, because it could be made much shorter and better fit in the Navigator and Package Explorer views.
90809: I20050406 There are a number of cases where 'null' is passed instead of the project's settings, resulting in not respecting the project's formatter options when rewriting.
142881: Build: 3.2 RC5 1. Open Plug-ins View 2. Double-click on any plug-in with a blue/purple icon (e.g. org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility.auth. A plug-in editor will open. 3. On the Overview page, select an item in the Execution Environments table. Press the DEL key. Observe how the selected item gets deleted. This should not happen. DEL key should do nothing on such a non-editable model.
76510: Adding overlay on the threads and monitor icons in the debug view to show deadlocks.
76513: Eclipse is unable to find source for nested (in this case twice) inner (named) classes when clicking on a strack trace in the console tab. The error window is displayed: "Source code not found for <classname>" Eclipse already *has* this information as it's clearly stated in human-readable form in the stack trace, which entries end with source file name and line number. I think that Eclipse should use this information and go to the line indicated on the stack trace entry being clicked on -- that's precisely what user is doing anyway.
76514: We should extend IDebugModelPresentation to allow clients to provide color for elements. This would allow, for example, JDT Debug to color threads red when they're in a deadlock.
105017: We have made a couple minor changes for performance to the Headers class. This change removes multiple calls to set() to replace an item and reorders the getIndex method. These changes show about 11% performance improvement on OSGi initialization (on a PocketPC 400mhz) when no bundles are installed.
76516: When a thread is involved in a deadlock, it should be colored red.
105018: I am using the Eclipse OSGi framework (the org.eclipse.osgi project from HEAD), and have an admin bundle that allows me to install, resolve, and start bundles. It uses the PackageAdmin service to report the status of the system. After each operation (install, resolve, or start) the bundle queries PackageAdmin and reports back the status. When the framework initially starts up, it reports the status correctly. If a bundle is then installed and resolved, PackageAdmin reports back incorrect package wiring for the new bundle. Note that the bundle has resolved correctly. This occurs because the BundleLoader object is created before the bundle is resolved. If the BundleLoader is only created after a bundle is resolved then it works ok. This can be done by changing the first 'if' condition in org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.BundleLoaderProxy.getBundleLoader() from: if (loader == null) { to: if (loader == null && bundle.isResolved()) {
152200: due to fix for bug 151702, descriptions are not stored in our schema models which is a good thing. In the New Extension wizard, we now parse the schema every time an extension point is selected to retrieve its description. but then, we don't keep track of visited extension points, we reparse when an extension point is selected again. Given that we already paid the memory penalty once upon the first parsing, it would be good if we cached descriptions until the wizard is dismissed.
76518: The Add, Remove, Move UP and Move Down buttons are not correctly sized if the dialog font (as set in the Eclipse preferences) is set to a larger font.
86793: LaunchConfigurationView handles help dynamically. It needs to expose itself as a context provider so to be help view-friendly. Patch forthcoming.
90803: I20050405-0800: Resource bundles which have been converted to the new format using org.eclipse.osgi.util.NLS#bind(...) do not work anymore with the common double- quote "escaping". The NLS class internally uses a custom implementation of MessageFormat, which only provides very limited functionality. Clients using some of the advanced features of the java.text.MessageFormat class are broken as well.

95611: The environment PATH variable is now included as part of the java.library.path that gets passed to ant when running a target. If there are quotes around an entry in this variable, eclipse does not escape them properly which makes the process fail with a "Java Virtual Machine Launcher" error. The message in the error is "Cannot find main class. program will exit". example of bad path entry: PATH="C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\VSS\win32";

105071: When launching a (CDT) session for a project that has a compile error, the user is asked whether he'd like to continue with the launch all the same. The launch is cancelled regardless of whether the user hits Yes or No. The reason is a bug in the platform function: org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.launchConfigurations. CompileErrorPromptStatusHandler.handleStatus() The code checks for a return code of IDialogConstants.OK_ID when it should be checking for IDialogConstants.YES_ID. John
92581: The all types cache has been removed from JDT and our "add exception breakpoint" dialog needs to catch up to the changes. We were referencing internal code.
83636: In eclipse 3.1 M5, TableTree will be deprecated. Please change LogView to use TreeViewer which now supports columns (including fonts, colours and cell editors). This is available as of the latest 3.1 Integration build (I20050125) Below are two examples of how to use the new API: public class TreeViewerTest { class TreeViewerTestLabelProvider implements ITableLabelProvider, ITableColorProvider, ITableFontProvider { Font font = null; public String getColumnText(Object element, int columnIndex) { if (!(element instanceof File)) return null; File file = (File)element; switch (columnIndex) { case 0: return file.getName(); case 1: return ""+new Date(file.lastModified()); case 2: return ""+file.isHidden(); } return null; } public Image getColumnImage(Object element, int columnIndex) { if (columnIndex != 0) return null; if (!(element instanceof File)) return null; File file = (File)element; Display display = Display.getCurrent(); if (file.isDirectory()) return display.getSystemImage (SWT.ICON_WARNING); return display.getSystemImage(SWT.ICON_QUESTION); } public void dispose() { if (font != null) font.dispose(); font = null; } public boolean isLabelProperty(Object element, String property) { return false; } public void addListener(ILabelProviderListener listener) { } public void removeListener(ILabelProviderListener listener) { } public Color getForeground(Object element, int columnIndex) { if (columnIndex == 1) { Display display = Display.getCurrent(); return display.getSystemColor(SWT.COLOR_RED); } return null; } public Color getBackground(Object element, int columnIndex) { if (columnIndex == 0) { File file = (File)element; Display display = Display.getCurrent(); if (file.isDirectory()) return display.getSystemColor(SWT.COLOR_CYAN); return display.getSystemColor (SWT.COLOR_MAGENTA); } return null; } public Font getFont(Object element, int columnIndex) { if (columnIndex == 2) { if (font == null) { Display display = Display.getCurrent(); font = new Font(display, "Times", 12, SWT.ITALIC); } return font; } return null; } } public static void main(String[] args) { final Display display = new Display(); final Shell shell = new Shell(display); shell.setLayout(new FormLayout()); TreeViewerTestLabelProvider labelProvider1 = new TreeViewerTest().new TreeViewerTestLabelProvider(); ITreeContentProvider contentProvider = new ITreeContentProvider() { public Object[] getChildren(Object parentElement) { if (!(parentElement instanceof File)) return null; File file = (File)parentElement; if (file.isDirectory()) return file.listFiles(); return null; } public Object getParent(Object element) { if (!(element instanceof File)) return null; File file = (File)element; return file.getParentFile(); } public boolean hasChildren(Object element) { if (!(element instanceof File)) return false; File file = (File)element; return file.isDirectory(); } public Object[] getElements(Object inputElement) { return getChildren(inputElement); } public void dispose() { } public void inputChanged(Viewer viewer, Object oldInput, Object newInput) { } }; ILabelProvider labelProvider2 = new ILabelProvider() { public void dispose() { } public boolean isLabelProperty(Object element, String property) { return false; } public void addListener(ILabelProviderListener listener) { } public void removeListener(ILabelProviderListener listener) { } public Image getImage(Object element) { if (!(element instanceof File)) return null; File file = (File)element; if (file.isDirectory()) return display.getSystemImage (SWT.ICON_WARNING); return display.getSystemImage(SWT.ICON_QUESTION); } public String getText(Object element) { if (!(element instanceof File)) return null; File file = (File)element; return file.getName(); } }; final TreeViewer treeViewer1 = new TreeViewer(shell, SWT.FULL_SELECTION | SWT.CHECK); Tree tree1 = treeViewer1.getTree(); tree1.setHeaderVisible(true); TreeColumn column1 = new TreeColumn(tree1, SWT.LEFT); column1.setText("Name"); column1.setImage(display.getSystemImage(SWT.ICON_WORKING)); column1.setWidth(200); TreeColumn column2 = new TreeColumn(tree1, SWT.CENTER); column2.setText("Last Modified"); column2.setImage(display.getSystemImage(SWT.ICON_INFORMATION)); column2.setWidth(200); TreeColumn column3 = new TreeColumn(tree1, SWT.CENTER); column3.setText("Hidden"); column3.setImage(display.getSystemImage(SWT.ICON_INFORMATION)); column3.setWidth(100); treeViewer1.setLabelProvider(labelProvider1); treeViewer1.setContentProvider(contentProvider); final TreeViewer treeViewer2 = new TreeViewer(shell); Tree tree2 = treeViewer2.getTree(); treeViewer2.setLabelProvider(labelProvider2); treeViewer2.setContentProvider(contentProvider); Button b = new Button(shell, SWT.PUSH); b.setText("choose root folder"); b.addListener(SWT.Selection, new Listener() { public void handleEvent(Event e) { DirectoryDialog f = new DirectoryDialog(shell, SWT.OPEN); String root = f.open(); if (root != null) { File file = new File(root); if (file.exists()) { treeViewer1.setInput(file); treeViewer1.refresh(); treeViewer2.setInput(file); treeViewer2.refresh(); } } } }); FormData data = new FormData(); data.left = new FormAttachment(0, 10); data.top = new FormAttachment(0, 10); data.right = new FormAttachment(50, -5); data.bottom = new FormAttachment(b, -10); tree1.setLayoutData(data); data = new FormData(); data.left = new FormAttachment(50, 5); data.top = new FormAttachment(0, 10); data.right = new FormAttachment(100, -10); data.bottom = new FormAttachment(b, -10); tree2.setLayoutData(data); data = new FormData(); data.left = new FormAttachment(0, 10); data.bottom = new FormAttachment(100, -10); b.setLayoutData(data); shell.open(); while (!shell.isDisposed()) { if (!display.readAndDispatch()) display.sleep(); } display.dispose(); } } Here is a second example using cell editors: public class TreeViewerTest2 { class TreeViewerTestLabelProvider implements ITableLabelProvider { Font font = null; public String getColumnText(Object element, int columnIndex) { if (!(element instanceof File)) return null; File file = (File)element; switch (columnIndex) { case 0: return file.getName(); case 1: return ""+new Date(file.lastModified()); case 2: return ""+file.isHidden(); } return null; } public Image getColumnImage(Object element, int columnIndex) { if (columnIndex != 0) return null; if (!(element instanceof File)) return null; File file = (File)element; Display display = Display.getCurrent(); if (file.isDirectory()) return display.getSystemImage (SWT.ICON_WARNING); return display.getSystemImage(SWT.ICON_QUESTION); } public void dispose() { if (font != null) font.dispose(); font = null; } public boolean isLabelProperty(Object element, String property) { return false; } public void addListener(ILabelProviderListener listener) { } public void removeListener(ILabelProviderListener listener) { } } public static void main(String[] args) { final Display display = new Display(); final Shell shell = new Shell(display); shell.setLayout(new FormLayout()); TreeViewerTestLabelProvider labelProvider1 = new TreeViewerTest2().new TreeViewerTestLabelProvider(); ITreeContentProvider contentProvider = new ITreeContentProvider() { public Object[] getChildren(Object parentElement) { if (!(parentElement instanceof File)) return null; File file = (File)parentElement; if (file.isDirectory()) return file.listFiles(); return null; } public Object getParent(Object element) { if (!(element instanceof File)) return null; File file = (File)element; return file.getParentFile(); } public boolean hasChildren(Object element) { if (!(element instanceof File)) return false; File file = (File)element; return file.isDirectory(); } public Object[] getElements(Object inputElement) { return getChildren(inputElement); } public void dispose() { } public void inputChanged(Viewer viewer, Object oldInput, Object newInput) { } }; ILabelProvider labelProvider2 = new ILabelProvider() { public void dispose() { } public boolean isLabelProperty(Object element, String property) { return false; } public void addListener(ILabelProviderListener listener) { } public void removeListener(ILabelProviderListener listener) { } public Image getImage(Object element) { if (!(element instanceof File)) return null; File file = (File)element; if (file.isDirectory()) return display.getSystemImage (SWT.ICON_WARNING); return display.getSystemImage(SWT.ICON_QUESTION); } public String getText(Object element) { if (!(element instanceof File)) return null; File file = (File)element; return file.getName(); } }; final TreeViewer treeViewer1 = new TreeViewer(shell, SWT.FULL_SELECTION | SWT.CHECK); Tree tree1 = treeViewer1.getTree(); tree1.setHeaderVisible(true); TreeColumn column1 = new TreeColumn(tree1, SWT.LEFT); column1.setText("Name"); column1.setWidth(200); TreeColumn column2 = new TreeColumn(tree1, SWT.CENTER); column2.setText("Last Modified"); column2.setWidth(200); TreeColumn column3 = new TreeColumn(tree1, SWT.CENTER); column3.setText("Hidden"); column3.setWidth(100); treeViewer1.setLabelProvider(labelProvider1); treeViewer1.setContentProvider(contentProvider); CellEditor editors[] = new CellEditor[tree1.getColumnCount()]; editors[0] = new TextCellEditor(tree1); final String[] dates = new String[] { "June 1, 1980", //$NON-NLS-1$ "May 30, 2002", //$NON-NLS-1$ "Feb 21, 2004" //$NON-NLS-1$ }; editors[1] = new ComboBoxCellEditor(tree1, dates, SWT.READ_ONLY); editors[2] = new CheckboxCellEditor(tree1); treeViewer1.setCellEditors(editors); final String[] tableColumnProperties = new String[] {"Name", "Last Modified", "Hidden"}; ICellModifier cellModifier = new ICellModifier() { public Object getValue(Object element, String property) { File file = (File) element; if (property.equals(tableColumnProperties[0])) { return file.getName(); } if (property.equals(tableColumnProperties[1])) { return new Integer(1); } if (property.equals(tableColumnProperties[2])) { return new Boolean(file.isHidden()); } return null; } public boolean canModify(Object element, String property) { return true; } public void modify(Object element, String property, Object value) { TreeItem item = (TreeItem) element; if (property.equals(tableColumnProperties[0])) { String string = (String)value; item.setText(0, string); } if (property.equals(tableColumnProperties[1])) { Integer integer = (Integer)value; item.setText(1, dates[integer.intValue()]); } if (property.equals(tableColumnProperties[2])) { Boolean bool = (Boolean)value; item.setChecked(bool.booleanValue()); item.setText(2, bool.toString()); } } }; treeViewer1.setCellModifier(cellModifier); treeViewer1.setColumnProperties(tableColumnProperties); Button b = new Button(shell, SWT.PUSH); b.setText("choose root folder"); b.addListener(SWT.Selection, new Listener() { public void handleEvent(Event e) { DirectoryDialog f = new DirectoryDialog(shell, SWT.OPEN); String root = f.open(); if (root != null) { File file = new File(root); 91249: (I'm using Eclipse 3.1M6+WTP1.0M3). In the Ant editor when an attribute value contains digits followed or preceded by hyphens, double clicking on them won't select the whole attribute value. This is somewhat annoying when attributes are meant to represent "identifiers", such as targets or properties names. Simple examples: <target name="target-name12345target-name" description="--> description"> <property name="prop-name5555prop-name" location="location"/> </target> <target name="targetname-12345targetname" description="--> description"> <property name="propname5555-propname" location="location"/> </target> In the first target everything is ok (hyphens don't prevent full name selection). In the second, by double clicking on the target name, just the part before or after the combination "hyphen/digit" is selected. In other words, hyphens block the selection when coupled with digits. Thanks
108114: Hi, I wanted to use the input task for selecting a name from a (valid) list of items. Therefore I feed the input tasks attribute "validargs" with an adequate formatted list. After starting the surrounding target, I discovered that the shown input dialog shows the valid values (inside brackets) by appending the list to the input message. Because the list has many items, only the start of the list is shown. I would suggest, that either the boundaries of the shown dialog have to be recalculated (which can result in an dialog, which cannot be displayed) or the displayed list have to be split automatically (by using carriage returns) to fit into the dialog.
109440: I just finished converting relatively large codebase to plugin projects and decided to share my experience and extensions to PDE I've made to make this job easier Our code used quite a few thirdparty labraries like log4j or jdom. New plugin from existing JAR is a nice wizard, but I found it annoying to look for JAR files on filesystem when I can see the JARs right in the Package Explorer view. I've added to action to invoke the wizard by right-clicking on one or several jar files from Package Explorer, Navigator or any other view. Another annoyance with New plugin from existing JAR wizard is that after importing say log4j.jar I had to manually update all projects that reference the jar and replace JAR-file reference with project reference. Really tedious. I've extented New plugin from existing JAR wizard with an option to do that automatically. After importing all my jars and converting all my projects to plugins, I've found that I had to manually add plugin dependencies even though this information was already available in .classpath files. Really, really tedious. To address this, I've introduced new "Update plugin dependencies..." action. After implementing these little enhancements, overall conversion was rather simple and quick job -- 1) created new plugins from jars which also established dependencies on the new plugins 2) converted projects to plugins 3) updated plugin dependencies 4) updated project classpath

123721: I've noticed for TODO type task tags (in Java Editor), there is a "remove task" action (from Ruler), that removes the task marker. But, the task is added again immediately when re-compiled, so removing it seems kind of not-very-useful. But, there is a "remove task tag" quick fix, that removes the task and the todo text giving rise to it, which is, to me, what users would want from the "remove task" action as well. So, I think either the actions should be equivent, or, the "remove task" action not shown for TODO type tasks (that would be quickly re-discovered).

84951: When a launch is created is registers a launch listener, debug event listener, and launch configuration listener. The listeners are removed when the launch is removed from the manager. If the launch is never registered/de-registered the listeners are not cleaned up. This is a problem for tools creating launch objects for private use that users cannot see in the UI.

83658: 3.1 M4 The WorkbenchAdvisor is currently overloaded with the responsibility to configure the workbench, all workbench windows, and the windows' action bars. This leads to either a large implementing advisor class, or to clients delegating to other objects in an ad-hoc way (e.g. the IDE's WorkbenchActionBuilder). Implementors often get state management wrong, keeping window-level state as fields on the (singleton) workbench advisor. The window-level responsibilities in WorkbenchAdvisor should be split out into a window-level advisor, WorkbenchWindowAdvisor. Action bar configuration split out as well into an ActionBarAdvisor. This will lead to a 1:1 correspondence between the advisors and the configurers. In addition, this opens up the possibility of allowing different window configurations within the same application (e.g. main window, help window, update window). Currently Help and Update have to resort to using a JFace ApplicationWindow to avoid unwanted menu contributions. These changes must not break any existing WorkbenchAdvisor implementations. Backwards compatibility should be provided via a CompatibilityWorkbenchWindowAdvisor, which will delegate to the old WorkbenchAdvisor methods.

95658: As part of plug-in startup and activation, anyone can call Display.readAndDispatch() to process UI events. This will also run any outstanding asyncExecs and syncExecs. For example, ModalContext.ModalContextThread#block calls readAndDispatch. This in turn is indirectly called by ProgressManager#run, which is called by CVS's AllRootsElement when the repositories view is created. The code that restores the Workbench is written in a way that it assumes no events are dispatched and no async/syncExecs are run before the 'real' UI event loop runs. This is a false assumption. I am attaching source for a modified UISynchronizer that delays at least the async/syncExecs until it is safe to run them. However, this creates a new problem in that ModalContext.ModalContextThread#block actually blocks forever because the syncExec in ModalContext.ModalContextThread#run is not being executed. We should either be prepared for anyone to call into Workbench methods even before we run the event loop, or use something along the lines of the attached UISycnhronizer to prevent this from happening.

91298: 20050413 For JDT, we thought of offering some transfers like 'code style settings', 'error and warning settings'. The problem with that is that such transfers would contain up to 100 of keys and all of them quite long. They have to be specified in the plugin.xml in a the key attribute. I would like to avoid having a super long line. First I tried to simply repeat the same node <mapping scope="instance"> <entry node="org.eclipse.jdt.core" keys="org.eclipse.jdt.core.codeComplete.fieldPrefixes,org.eclipse.jdt.core.codeComplete.fieldSuffixes"/> <entry node="org.eclipse.jdt.core" keys="org.eclipse.jdt.core.codeComplete.argumentPrefixes,org.eclipse.jdt.core.codeComplete.argumentSuffixes"/> ... </mapping> This doesn't seem to be supported, the schema description doesn't mention that this wouldn't work The second approach was to use the internalization feature <mapping scope="instance"> <entry node="org.eclipse.jdt.core" keys="%alljdtcore_codestylekeys"/> </mapping> this works, but this seems to be the wrong approach to me. I would suggest to allow to use the same node more than once or introcude a new subnode <mapping scope="instance"> <entry node="org.eclipse.jdt.core"> <key="org.eclipse.jdt.core.codeComplete.fieldPrefixes"/> <key="org.eclipse.jdt.core.codeComplete.fieldSuffixes"/> ... </entry> </mapping>
108144: The undo and redo action handlers provide an IAdaptable that describes ui info about the triggering action. Currently they can provide their progress monitor, undo context, workbench part, etc., and answer null for unknown requests. It would be better if they pass the adapter request on to their part if they don't recognize the class. In this way, more part-specific information can be provided. For example, an editor part could provide its text viewer, etc., which is useful for the responding undo manager.

82344: All of these pages really could present the data better with a table with column headers etc. The tasks page is especially ugly. Allows for better presentation with bug 56072 as well.
83674: Version: 3.1.0 Build id: I20050125-0800 There is a note at the bottom of the file types preference page that some entires in the list can be changed but not removed. When a contributed item is selected the remove button should be disabled. It might also be a nice idea to set the background colour of contributed items to indicate that they are 'special'. I have a patch which adds this functionality. The patch will also turn table lines on to be consistent with most of the other tables in the workbench. (This change is purely optional) A further enhancement might be to display an icon on the table to indicate the current item type (name or extension) as well as its type (binary or text).
82345: The delete key should initiate a remove of the selected structure.
82346: Not working (CLabel disappears): ... CLabel label = new CLabel(composite, SWT.SHADOW_IN | SWT.CENTER); label.setLayoutData(new GridData(GridData.FILL_HORIZONTAL)); ... Workaround: ... CLabel label = new CLabel(composite, SWT.SHADOW_IN); label.setAlignment(SWT.CENTER); label.setLayoutData(new GridData(GridData.FILL_HORIZONTAL)); ... Noticed this on Linux (gtk) , Eclipse 3.1M4
131330: 3.2M5 I currently moved to a new PC which had different drive letters. I start up one Eclipse instance, and then in there run a second instance under the debugger. In the launch configuration I still had the old path name to my workspace, like "D:\workspace". But that's not right anymore (everything is on C:). So when I tried to launch the second instance (Run > Debug...) I got an error dialog, but the message was misleading. It said: "Workspace Cannot be Locked Could not launch the product because the associated workspace is currently in use." It's not in use, it's completely missing. Also it would be nice for it to tell me what workspace directory it was complaining about since I have several.
157944: 3.3 m2 test candidate 1. On the overview page of the plugin editor, make sure the Activator field is empty. 2. Click the Activator link. The class wizard opens with an error. This is a UI faux-pas. I suspect this is a regression due to fix for bug 101644
96974: I20050527-0010: Use snippet: @SuppressWarnings({"javadoc","nls"}) class Test<T> { String test= ""; } with javadoc processing and nls checking enabled
109482: When comparing files it should be possible to search within the open files. Ctrl+F doesn't work and the Edit/Replace entry is greyed out. This is a feature that I find very useful when comparing revisions of some file to make sure that some text is not present in that version.

84999: I noticed that line breakpoints can no longer be set in external files. Watchpoints and method breakpoints still work.
84998: Eclipse 3.0.1 In our application we provide code assist to our own Java editor. In order to be consistent with the JDT Java editor we need to provide the same look and feel for code assist (icons, ordering, display string, etc...). Currently the only way we can get that to work is using the internal class ResultCollector. Since ResultCollector is basically an implementation of ICompletionRequestor, would it be possible to make it API or at least provide the functionality to people implementing code assist for Java-like editors?

93014: Build: I20050426 The PreferenceForward.setValue(...) methods forward the request to the new preference service even if the value being set is the same as the old value. Since these methods are already comparing the old value and the new value to determine if change events should be broadcast, it would be trivial to optimize this case to completely avoid hitting the new preference store.
98707: It would be usefull if the Apply Patch functionality had public API. Other plug-ins may obtain patches from different sources (ie. bugzilla) and there should be a standard way to launch the Apply Patch functionality. I think this could be achieved by making org.eclipse.compare.internal.patch.CompareWithPatchAction public and by adding a mutator to set the patch location. The wizard could then be launched with the path to the patch already in the dialog. Also, the current implementation relys on a project being selected (since that is the only way to apply a patch AFAIK). A check for a null target in org.eclipse.compare.internal.patch.InputPatchPage will allow no project to be selected (in the event that focus is in another view when the wizard is launched). thoughts?
95675: On the Ant runtime classpath pref page, the order of buttons is different than on other lists with buttons: JDT UI uses: 'New' or 'Add', 'Edit', 'Remove', 'Up' & 'Down'
94349: build i0510-0010 WorkbenchActionBuilder#makeFeatureDependantActions calls Platform#getPlatformAdmin and then asks for the state and its timestamp. We have created a new method Platform#getStateStamp so you are now able to call that directly and not rely on the internals of the runtime. See bug 93663.
94348: Platform#getStateStamp has been created so ContentDescriptionManager#getPlatformTimestamp is no longer needed.
95672: To reproduce: 1. Run Eclipse in your favorite profiler 2. Open the Java browsing perspective 3. Profile the time taken to switch between java editors On my system, approx. 50% of the time is spent in JavaBrowsingPart.partBroughtToTop. Notice that this method continues to dominate activation changes, even when another perspective is active and no java browsing parts are visible.
109452: The Import and Export wizards for PSF files should remember previous files. As it is now it remembers the previous file used during one session. No history at all is persisted today. Another extreme annoyance is that the import wizard doesn't care about your right-clicked psf file in a navigator/package explorer. I also suggest a combobox is used instead of the text field to keep track of a history of earlier referenced PSF files. To help with the resolution of this defect I have implemented the suggested changes. I will attach a zip with the sources.
114801: This is for after 3.2 M3, but I wanted to make a note of it while it was on my mind. The resource info property page (ResourceInfoPage) needs some updates to support changes made to IResource in 3.2. 1) Update reference to IResource.getLocation(). Resource location may now be an arbitrary URI, and there is no API (IResource.getLocationURI()) for obtaining the resource location. I suggest first calling getLocation(), and if the result is null use getLocationURI instead. 2) IResource.getLocation().toFile() should not be used. This is used in a number of places to check if the file exists on disk, and for obtaining the local file's last modified time. There is other API that can be used in each case. A guide is available here: http://eclipse.org/eclipse/platform-core/documents/3.2/flexible_workspaces/migration.html 3) The size of the resource can now be computed using API on IFileStore instead of java.io.File (store.fetchInfo().getLength()). This will allow the size to be showed correctly when other protocols are used. 4) The "hidden" file attribute is now supported on Windows. Also, API is now available to determine the set of attributes that apply on a given platform (IFileStore.getFileSystem().attributes())). This could be used to avoid showing attributes that don't apply (such as "executable" on Windows or "archive" on non-Windows file systems).
93010: I0426, found with FindBugs The "if" statement starting at SessionPropertySyncInfoCache line 354 looks like it wants to avoid the throw that happens in line 361 in certain cases, but since the throw is not in an else block, it will still get hit even if the status code is one of the IResourceStatus constants being checked for.

122421: I revised and improved my plugin on which Eclipse export filter is based on. The sources are available in the download jar: http://www.geocities.com/richard_hoefter/eclipse2ant/ I touched many lines and diff is very long, but I tested with JDK 1.4/1.5, Windows/Linux and Eclipse 3.1/3.1.1/3.2M4. So I'm quite sure that the new version is stable. Before I dump the changelog, here is the summary of most important new features: - Version control support (Tested with ClearCase and Subversion Plugins) - Support different classpaths for runtime configuration - Analyze project for Ant compatibility - Support Eclipse compiler - Enhance wizard - Don't create build-user.xml any more, instead import files with special comment <!-- eclipse.import --> using <import> not with &entity_reference; Here now the list of sources that need to be checked in CVS, all other files stay unchanged (except the package name I had to change). Existing bug IDs that got fixed are also listed. AntBuildfileExportPage.java - Extend wizard with new options Buttons: (De)select all Checkbox: Check projects for Ant compatibility Checkbox: Create target to compile project using Eclipse compiler Textfield: Name for Ant buildfile 89751 Textfield: JUnit output directory - Add progess bar AppletUtil.java - Indent HTML file - Add comment that file is generated - Create file contents, not file, so that caller can sync with filesystem BuildFileCreator.java - Fix: Compile different source dirs to different class dirs - Support progess monitor - Support version control plugins - Export debug options - Check source cycles and classpath order - Don't import and create build-user.xml by default, instead import XML files with special comment <!-- eclipse.import --> - Ensure correct order of <property> tags - Copy resources according to Eclipse settings - Support "." as source directory (clean *.class) - Create new target cleanall to clean subprojects, too - Split build target into build-subprojects/build-project: - Create targets to compile with Eclipse compiler init-eclipse-compiler, build-eclipse-compiler - Support bootclasspath (compiler and runtime) - Create target junitreport - Confirm overwrite of applet HTML file - Generate relative paths whereever possible - Sort JUnit tests in testsuites DataTransferMessages.java DataTransferMessages.properties EclipseClasspath.java - Create separate classpath for user library - Support runtime classpath if different from project classpath 96789 - Support linked resources 104748 - Support plugin dependencies ExportUtil.java - resolve(): Allow project root as argument - getClasspathProjects() resturns List instead of Set to preserve compile order - remove addEntity(): No more used - Moved existsUserFile() from AntBuildfileExportPage - Add methods for version control support - Moved addVariable() from BuildFileCreator SourceAnalyzer.java - API to analyze if source directories of a project have cycles and correct buildpath order
102813: I20050627-1435 (3.1) When comparing large text files, the vertical scroll synchronization does not work when the caret is placed towards the end of a file. The other pane always scrolls to top. Steps: - create a new file A.txt - copy the contents of StyledText and append it 7 times to A.txt - copy A.txt to B.txt and add line "xxx" to B.txt - compare A.txt and B.txt with each other - move the caret in the first editor to the end of the file => second file is not scrolled down - move the vertical scrollbar thumb up and down => editors are only synchronized above ca. line 38400
152294: In the following snippet: <extension point="org.eclipse.ui.perspectiveExtensions"> <perspectiveExtension targetID="org.eclipse.ui.resourcePerspective"> <perspectiveShortcut id="org.eclipse.jdt.ui.JavaPerspective"> </perspectiveShortcut> </perspectiveExtension> </extension> According to the extension point schema, you can have 0 or more <perspectiveShortcut> elements inside <perspectiveExtension>. However, if you have one such element, content assist no longer shows you 'perspectiveShortcut' as proposal. Same applies for other elements too.
93002: I0426, found with FindBugs RemoveFolder line 232 looks like: if ((flags & EXISTING_MEMBERS) == 0 && (flags & PHANTOM_MEMBERS) == 1) { But PHANTOM_MEMBERS has value 64, so (flags & PHANTOM_MEMBERS) can never evaluate to 1. I'm guessing that this line should be: if ((flags & (EXISTING_MEMBERS | PHANTOM_MEMBERS)) == PHANTOM_MEMBERS) {
94333: The code which performs a read() on a LongLink name in TarInputStream does not check if it has read the entire name. This causes errors when importing tar files with long names.
93008: I0426, found with FindBugs 1. ConfirmMergedOperation line 72 invokes cvsInfo.getLocal(), but the if statement in line 71 makes cvsInfo == null the condition for getting into the block, so this will NPE if cvsInfo == null. 2. Command line 274 has a similar issue since folder == null is one of the ways to get into the if block. 3. Update line 166 has a similar issue since folder == null is one of the ways to get into the if block. 4. CommitSetDialog line 187 looks like: if (name == null && name.length() == 0) { But name can never be null, so setPageComplete(false) never gets to happen here. (Note that FindBugs flagged this as a potential NPE as a result of using && instead of ||, but since Text.getText() never answers null, the null check can just be removed in this line).
95665: N20050517-0010 Window>Preferences>General>Editors The 3 "linked" text messages at the top of the page are not setting the dialog font Same for the File Associations and Content Types pages
95662: When a debug element is selected, we enable associated activities. The bindings for activities are specified like: <activityPatternBinding activityId="org.eclipse.javaDevelopment" pattern="org\.eclipse\.jdt\.debug/debugModel"> </activityPatternBinding> We fail to match debug model id "org.eclipse.jdt.debug" to "org\.eclipse\.jdt\.debug". We should either specify that the pattern is no a regex, or we should properly parse it in LaunchViewContextListener.
95663: Current the Ant xml formatter inserts new lines using System.getProperty("line.separator"). This will cause problems if the document is edited/formatted on muliple platforms. We should be using TextUtilities.getDefaultLineDelimiter(IDocument)
102826: Allow highlighting of the individual differences when doing a compare. Preferences have been added to allow you to control the colors used for foreground and background. If the same color is used for both foreground and background (as is the with default settings) then the background is made lighter and the foreground darker.
86717: When hippie completion is executed on a large file (~ 4000 code lines) it takes several seconds to compute all possible completions. I think the following may improve the completion speed. 1. Lazy completion - only compute the next possible completion each time the action is executed. 2. Backwards search may be slower than forward search. It should be possible to perform a forward search and reverse the results. I will try to provide a patch before M6.

98048: The "Terminate and Remove" action in the pop-up menu of the Launch View doesn't assure the complete termination of the launch object. If a child of the launch object is selected and the action is triggered, the child gets terminated and the launch removed. But there is no check, whether the launch had other children still running and the launch isn't terminated itself, either.

116924: Build: I20051115 NewFolderDialog.isValidContainer checks if a given container is a valid parent of a linked resource. Note that the code to check for validation based on project nature should still be there. This dialog is used by the Java build path property page. To make it appear, select the "Source" tab, click "Add Folder", and then click "Create New Folder" from the next dialog. This dialog should have an "Advanced" button even when the parent is another folder.

77116: The breakpointContainerFactories extension point is spec'd to require clients subclass an internal class - AbstractBreakpointContainerFactory, which implements an internal interface (IBreakpointContainerFactory). The API classes for extension points have to be in public packages. However, to enforce lazy plug-in loading, would it be better to have a delegate interface that clients provide an implementation for - IBreakpointContainerFactoryDelegate, that implements the methods createContainers(IBreakpointContainer) and dispose()? Then, the platform provides an implementation of IBreakpointContainerFactory that simply delegates to the delegate.

98030: If you have two views that are getting content from the same input at the same time, the DeferredTreeContentManager will cancel the background content fetching of one of the views. In my case, this happens almost everytime I start the workbench because I've got a few views that are using the same input (a "manager" style object). The problem stems from the following code inside the Job: public boolean belongsTo(Object family) { return isParent(family, parent); } private boolean isParent(Object family, Object child) { if (family.equals(child)) return true; ... } The comments on this code indicate that it's intended to cancel a job that's fetching children for an object that gets refreshed. But because we're using such a weak check, "conflicts" can be detected from separate views. I think this bug can be fixed by imposing another check: Besides checking if the job is fetching children for the same object, we should also check if it's fetching children for the same deferredtreecontentmanager.

112533: ant.ui requires jdt.ui, but it defines a second "Format" command and places it in the "Source" category. This means that it is very hard to display in the keys preference page. The only translated piece of text that distinguishes them is the description. A description is hard to show in a list. The recommended way to use commands is to have one command for every semantic (e.g., format) and then provide your own handler within the appropriate application context (e.g., editor, view, etc.). It also makes it challenging for users to change the format key binding. If a user wants F11 to be format and every editor provided their own format command, then they have to go around and change every editor's format key binding. It would be nice if ant.ui simply used the jdt.ui format.

247027: When including binary features in the build, requested versions to include in the state have a specific version. A specific version is incorrectly being excluded from the state. Fix is to use [0.0.0, 0.0.0) as the bound on the sorted subset, and have ReachablePlugin account for inclusion of the maximum when sorting.

86078: Hello, I'm testing my plugins for use on 3.1 (EclipseME... http://eclipseme.org). I have a wizard that creates a new J2ME project which is mostly just a Java project with some minor differences. My wizard consists of a WizardNewProjectCreationPage, a custom page and a subclass of JavaCapabilityConfigurationPage. In 3.0, everything works well and has for quite some time. Unfortunately, the code as it currently stands fails with a JavaModelException due to some changes in 3.1. My capability page attempts to init the capability page when it is switched to by the user. That init fails with the attached stack trace. Looking at the JDT UI code, it appears that for some reason the new Java Project wizard is doing a LOT of the project setup work in JavaProjectWizardSecondPage which is not public API. It appears that all of the BuildPathsBlock code is either not used or extraneous with the current second page implementation. I don't believe this is how it should work. As it stands, I would need to reimplement all of the code in internalConfigureJavaProject and the methods it calls in order to be able to use the code as it is. My guess is that because of these changes, the base JavaCapabilityConfigurationPage is not being correctly tested. My current implementation (that worked in 3.0) looks like: void updateConfiguration() { // Work out the project and path information IProject project = getNewProjectCreatePage().getProjectHandle(); IJavaProject javaProject = JavaCore.create(project); IPath projectPath = project.getFullPath(); // Initialize the classpath entries using the source directories // and classpath container ArrayList entryList = new ArrayList(); entryList.add(getSrcPathEntry(projectPath)); addResourcesDirectoryIfRequested(entryList, project); entryList.add(JavaCore.newContainerEntry(new Path(J2MEClasspathContainer.J2ME_CONTAINER))); IClasspathEntry[] entries = (IClasspathEntry[]) entryList.toArray(new IClasspathEntry[entryList.size()]); init(javaProject, null, entries, false); } The init is where 3.0 would have taken care of all of the work that the second page is now doing. In addition, it seems that most of that project setup code is now in two places. What am I missing here? I'd rather not recreate all of this code, but will if I have to. This appears to be an API bug to me. 82500: Due to the nature of the widget PtPanelGroup, you cannot use PtCalcCanvas to get the widgets drawing area. There is a limitation in photon where you cannot draw a surface outside of a widgets canvas. The tabs are control surfaces. Therefore if you use PtCalcCanvas to determine the drawing area, you will overwrite the tabs. I will attach a patch to fix this.

98075: I've searched briefly for this problem in this bugzilla but with little success. It took me 6 hours to find this so I've decided to report it here without 100% certaninty that I'm not reporting a duplicate. The situation is like this: There are two ordiranry java projects J_1 and J_2. J_2 depends on J_1. There are also 3 plugin projects P_1, P_2 and P_3. P_3 depends on P_2 and P_2 depends on P_1. J_1 contents are packed into a jar and copied to P_1 which exports this J_1.jar. J_2 contents are packed into a jar and copied to P_2 which exports this J_2.jar. We have eclipse application launch configuration - let's call it RUN_WORKSPACE. Everything works perfect - new workspace is created all 3 plugins work in it. Now let's add new package to J_1 with interface definition - IMyInterface. Let's create a class that implements this interface in J_2 - MyClass Let's compile, update the jars, referesh the plugins. Let's extend this class in P_3 with MyExtClass - we can do it now, both MyClass and IMyInterface are visible in P_3 from jars in P_2 and P_1. Run again RUN_WORKSPACE. Now when loading class MyExtClass there will be NoClassDefFoundError - IMyInterface thrown. The problem is that IMyInterface was definied in a new package - this is very important. If IMyInterface was definied in previously existing package everything would work just fine. I have noticed some kind of cache in .metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.pde.core\RUN_WORKSPACE that contains package names - after deleting this directory everything started to work. The cache was rebuild and new package with IMyInterface showed there. Sorry for complicated report - I tried to put is as simple as possible but I realize this report is quite complicated. I'm running 3.1M7 Maciek
77146: This bug is being reported on Eclipse 3.0.0 GM code base. In org.eclipse.osgi/eclipseAdapter/src/org/eclipse/core/runtime/adaptor/EclipseStarter.java, when using an alternalte VM class format (specifically j9 JXE in this case), any calls to FOO.class.getProtectionDomain().getCodeSource().getLocation().getFile() return "". We worked around this problem by querying the SystemBundleData.OSGI_FRAMEWORK environment variable to get the path needed (which is set by org.eclipse.platform at startup). This bug is a request to have this change made in the eclipse head branch. Source patch for eclipse 3.0.0 GM stream to follow... This code patch simply tries the fix described above and then calls the original code if it fails. The original code can likely be removed at the discression of the fixer.

89127: Create a new UpdateSite project. Check the box under Web Resources to Generate a web page listing ... Open up site.xsl. The encoding tag is set to ISO... <xsl:output method="html" encoding="ISO-8859-1"/> On Linux, the file is created with UTF-8 codepage, but the encoding tag is ISO-8859-1, which doesn't match. On windows, the file is created in windows codepage. These must be in UTF-8 for NLV characters to correctly display. site.xml is the same way. Also, index.html has no charset tag set on creation. This causes incorrect display of NLV characters.

102326: Java keystores ( JKS, JCEKS format), and keytool allow for creating signing certificates with a keypass. If a signing certificate has been stored in the keystore with a keypass, it can not be used for signing with the present implementation. The keypass field value can be optionally supplied (i.e. can be left blank if the associated keyEntry value has not been stored with a keypass). Please add a keypass field to the JarSigning Wizard page, and update any ant build templates as specified in "Bugzilla Bug 100534 Support for jarsigning in PDE scripts".

116931: Build: I20051115 There are two new validation methods on TeamHook: public IStatus validateCreateLink(IFile file, int updateFlags, URI location) public IStatus validateCreateLink(IFolder folder, int updateFlags, URI location) The default implementation of these methods calls the IPath-based validation method if the URI is local, and return OK_STATUS otherwise. The team plugin's team hook may want to override to provide a different implementation. Also, linked resources can now be created at arbitrary depth. Thus validateCreateLink will now be called for resources below the project level, which did not occur in Eclipse 3.1 or earlier.

103694: If a bundle Dynamically imports a package it is possible that a dynamic import resolution will override a package from a required bundle. For example: Bundle-SymbolicName: A Require-Bundle: B1 DynamicImport-Package: b Bundle-SymbolicName: B1 Export-Package: b Bundle-SymbolicName: B2 Export-Package: b In this case Bundle "A" will attempt to load a class in package "b" from Bundle "B1". If the class is not found then an attempt to dynamically import package "b" will be attempted. This could result in Bundle "A" importing package "b" from Bundle "B2". This dynamic import from "B2" will override any classes in package "b" from "B1". Before attempting to resolve a dynamic import a check is needed to ensure that package is not already provided by a required bundle.

99314: I20050610-0010 - Enable preference General > Workspace > Refresh automatically - close a project - restart eclipse -> A message is written to the log for each closed project: "Resource /xxx is not open." MonitorManager#getResourcesToMonitor() swallows the stacktrace of the CoreException. You should never just log e.getStatus(). Either create and log a new status that wraps the original exception, or don't log the exception if it is not important.
90975: 3.1 M6 I've written an RCP application that implememnts a MessageConsole using org.eclipse.ui.console. The console instance is added to the console manager in the bundle's start() method and when the console view is shown my console is shown . When another Workbench window is opened, the console view still contains the console instance and every works fine. However if I close on of the windows, the console in the remaining window becomes empty, it's although closing of the first console view causes the console instance to be removed from the console manager. At this point there is no way for the user to get the console instance back. It's really easy to duplicate - if you need help just let me know.
86000: The ImageLoader Save function appears to be producing bad JPG images. I have only verified this with JPEG output. Simple test case below loads PNG Files and Saves them as JPEG. Many files were tested and the majority did produced the proper JPG images as expected. The attached Zip file contains only those files that did not save correctly to JPEG. package com.ibm.test.image; import org.eclipse.swt.*; import org.eclipse.swt.graphics.*; public class ImageLoaderTest { public static void main(String[] args) { ImageLoader loader; String dir="c:\\image-problems\\"; String files[]={ "s34i3p04", "s34n3p04", "s35i3p04", "s35n3p04", "s36i3p04", "s36n3p04", "s37i3p04", "s37n3p04", "s38i3p04", "s38n3p04", "s39i3p04", "s39n3p04" }; try { for (int i=0; i<files.length; i++) { String filein = dir+files[i]+".png"; String fileout = dir+files[i]+".jpg"; loader = new ImageLoader(); loader.load(filein); loader.save(fileout,SWT.IMAGE_JPEG); } } catch (SWTException e) { e.printStackTrace(); } } }
103669: The OSGi spec states that duplicate import packages should not be allowed, but duplicate export packages are okay. Our current implementation fails to install a bundle containing duplicate export packages. A proposed fix will be attached to this PR.

88656: build I20050315 + latest UI from head With the move of the component framework to internals, IWorkbench was left extending IServiceProvider, which is now internal. This needs to be removed for M6. (Note that Doug and I were discussing making IWorkbench extend IAdaptable to provide the command/handler/etc services.)
88653: Build: I20050315 Setup: 1) Workspace with three projects, org.eclipse.jdt.core, org.eclipse.swt, and org.eclipse.swt.win32 2) Editor open on org.eclipse.jdt.internal.compiler.parser.Parser.java 3) Default Java perspective and Resource perspective open My test was to switch between the two open perspectives about five times using Ctrl+F8. The profiler showed 50% of the time in ParameterizedCommand.equals() and in the methods called by that equals implementation (Util.equals() and Command.equals()). The main problem is probably in the number of times this method is called (about 1.6 million times). This seems to be caused by a large number of property change events: ExternalActionManager$CommandCallback.bindingManagerChanged is called 30 times. This in turn calls ActionContributionItem$1.propertyChange, which is called 4787 times. The number of method calls explodes as you go down the call stack, until the equals method that is called 1.6 million times. I will attach profiler output to show more details. If the number of change events can't be reduced, it looks like the implementation of ParameterizedCommand.equals() can be made faster by first comparing the cached hash code. Only if the hash codes are the same does it need to do the remainder of the equality testing.
106705: If I create a feature that references a plugin that is not in the workspace but is installed (hence in the list fo available plugins for my feature) and attempt to create an ant build file for that feature in the UI, I get a null pointer exception. I think it is somewhat normal that the script generation does not work properly in the UI in that case, since the build script *cannot* be saved since the plugin is not in the workspace. But having a better feedback to the user would be appreciable. May be somthing like verifying 1st that all the feature plugins are available in the workspace, and if not giving a proper pop-up message, rather than trying to do something that is impossible and crashing with a NPE.
79709: Currently, launching preferences are distributed among the preference pages and launch config type tabs in the LCD: * The LCD contains perspective switching settings (i.e. which perspective to switch to for a config * mode) * The pref pages contain the following launch related settings: - Activate the workbench when a breakpoint is hit - Activate the debug view when a breakpoint is hit - Switch to associated perspective when an application suspends - the entire "Launching" pref page We should have all launching related preferences in one place. Moving the persepctive settings away from the LCD will reduce confusion for new users of the LCD, and free space for enhanced/improved configuration creation/instructions.

99337: If you import the org.eclipse.osgi plugin from a 3.0.x build into your workspace, the plugin will not compile as its classpath container references itself. This is because the 3.0.x org.eclipse.osgi plugin's Import-Package header lists packages from itself. PDE does not check for such usage of Import-Package and hence osgi gets put on its own container.

80707: LaunchConfiguration.launch() calls preLaunchCheck() before calling launch(..) launch(..) calls AntLaunchDelegate.launch(..) which does preLaunchCheck(..) again. -> Launch a build file that has break points in run mode and you will be asked twice if you want to use debug mode instead. Makes an annoying feature worse :-)

88677: Build: I20050315 We have added instrumentation to the platform that records UIJobs that take a long time to run. One such job that has turned up several times is AbstractDebugEventHandler$EventProcessingJob. We have seen this job running from 500 to 2000 milliseconds (see bug 88096 for raw data). This isn't terrible, but it creates blips where the UI is not responsive for user-noticeable delays. I see this job processes a maximum of 50 debug events in one execution. I suggest instead running for a bounded period to time, such as 200 milliseconds or until the queue is empty, whichever comes first. That way we have a bound on the time that this job will occupy the UI thread at one go.
86013: Build: 3.1 M5a Currently failed performance events are written to the platform log file. These events should be written to a separate file to avoid cluttering the main log file.
104104: To consider with launch simplification: Currently the property tests for 'isMainType' and 'isApplet' are part of the java debug UI plug-in (JavaElementPropertyTester), which means the plug-in must be loaded for the property testers to be effective. By moving to the launching plug-in the testers will be loaded sooner (as JUI pre-reqs lanuching), meaning that the available launch options will be better scoped sooner, reducing the available options in the run/debug cascade.

79752: enum XXX { A { void foo() {}}; } - currently there is now API to access the typ[e binding of the anonymous enum created by { void foo() {}} To make anonymous enums more consistent with AnonymousClassDeclaration the EnumConstantDeclaration should have a subnode AnonymousEnumDeclaration. The AnonymousEnumDeclaration would then resolve to a ITypeBinding. As with type declarations there should be an abstract class AbstractAnonymousTypeDeclaration which works as a super class for AnonymousEnumDeclaration and AnonymousTypeDeclaration.

88699: Update should refrain from storing absolute paths in the configuration area. The intention is to support the scenario requested by bug 88234: running from a read-only, movable, pre-initialized location. The framework is being changed to support that. We are (politely) asking other plug-ins that write to the configuration area to do the same.
78418: Provide a user interface to allow users to define their own logical structures as user preferences. The UI should be available as a pref page and from the variables view/expressions view.
88697: When we ship a plug-in as a single JAR file, the libraries that it includes are nested within the JAR. As a result, #loadLibary extracts these libraries to a location on disk so the system can access them. There is a problem on HP-UX (and perhaps other systems) that requires libraries to have permissions of 755. Currently when we extract them through the java.util.zip APIs, the permissions from the original file are not copied. Tom and I talked about this and for tomorrow's integration build we will put a chmod call into EclipseBundleData#searchVariants. In the future we would like to consider changing BundleFile and adding a new #getFile method that takes file permissions.
87363: Bug introduced Nov 5, 2004. Prior to change Control.showMenu did this: boolean showMenu (int x, int y) { Event event = new Event (); event.x = x; event.y = y; sendEvent (SWT.MenuDetect, event); if (!event.doit) return true; if (menu != null && !menu.isDisposed ()) { if (x != event.x || y != event.y) { menu.setLocation (event.x, event.y); } menu.setVisible (true); return true; } return false; } If a menu was created during the MenuDetect listener notification, the menu field was updated and the menu was set visible. After Nov 5, 2004 the method was moved to Widget and now looks like this: boolean showMenu (Menu menu, int x, int y) { Event event = new Event (); event.x = x; event.y = y; sendEvent (SWT.MenuDetect, event); if (!event.doit) return true; if (menu != null && !menu.isDisposed ()) { if (x != event.x || y != event.y) { menu.setLocation (event.x, event.y); } menu.setVisible (true); return true; } return false; } Since menu is just a local variable, it is not updated when a menu is created in the MenuDetect event. The following example demonstrates the problem: public static void main(String[] args) { Display display = new Display(); final Shell shell = new Shell(display); shell.addListener(SWT.MenuDetect, new Listener() { int count = 0; public void handleEvent(Event event) { Menu menu = shell.getMenu(); if (menu != null) menu.dispose(); menu = new Menu(shell, SWT.POP_UP); MenuItem item = new MenuItem(menu, SWT.PUSH); item.setText("Menu " + count++); shell.setMenu(menu); } }); shell.pack(); shell.open(); while (!shell.isDisposed()) { if (!display.readAndDispatch()) display.sleep(); } display.dispose(); }

84224: To get rid of the all types cache we have done several performance measurements how to best calculate the number of duplicate types names (e.g. same type name, but in different package). This information is essential for the organize import actions and the import rewriter. In a workspace containing all SDK plug-ins there are 1798!! duplicate type names: The different searches we tested. - searching for all types in a given scope. For example all types visible in org.eclipse.jdt.ui. This reports 20671 matches and takes between 1.31 s and 1.86 s without us doing any analysis to find duplicate types. - we search for all type names in a given type-container. A type container is either a package or a type with it package qualification if it is a nested type (e.g. pack.Type.InnerType the type container is pack.Type). Such a search doesn't exist yet, but we simulated it with a package as a type container. The result for the package "org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.text" is 89 types and takes between 220 ms and 250 ms. For the organize import we would search for all type containers which have a star import (e.g. end with '*'). Doing this in a loop we will spend the same time as for the all types search when searching for 4 - 5 type containers. If clients use star imports they will easily have 4 - 5 star imports. - We search for duplicate types for all types that are used unqualified in the source code to see if we have more than one match. For Assert in the scope of org.eclipse.jdt.ui we get 13 matches. This takes between 140 and 190 ms. The current results aren't in a range where we can convert the import structure to use the search engine without having a noticable performance degradation. So the question is: - is there a better search/algorithm we can use ? - can we add a special query to the search engine which than can be optimized ? For example a search query that reports all types in an array of type containers so that we only scan the index once.
84227: A call to AdapterManager#getAdapter(Object, String) will NPE if the adapter factory registered via XML is not yet loaded. I will attach a patch that fixes the problem.
86887: If you set a JSP breakpoint with the condition "true == false", it is still hit. The reason seems to be that in JavaLineBreakpoint.handleConditionalBreakpointEvent(), the call to getJavaProject returns null. This seems to be the case because JavaModelManager.create(IFile, IJavaProject) assumes that the File is a java file, a class file or an archive file. Since this is a JSP file that is passed through, it returns null rather than the correct source element.

94498: n20050509 Existing user settings for content types are not being loaded. The reason is that we are using ContentTypeCatalog#getContentType to obtain the content type corresponding to a preference node name, but that that method only returns validated content types. Since validation only happens after preferences were applied, no existing settings are being recognized. Fix: either apply preferences after validation, or use internalGetContentType (which ignores validation status).

98853: The Ant editor will pick up macrodefs and provide auto-completion of the macro (and jump to definition when requested) as expected if the macrodef has _no_ uri. Putting the macrodef in a namespace by setting the 'uri' attribute will break this behaviour (the actual build.xml runs ok in ant, its just the editor which fails to see the definition). This behavior was found regardless of location of macrodef (ie, external file imported or inline in the build.xml). --- Sample build.xml --- <project name="test" default="run-macro" xmlns:xyz="http://xyz" > <macrodef name="echo-macro" uri="http://xyz"> <attribute name="str"/> <sequential> <echo>@{str}</echo> </sequential> </macrodef> <target name="run-macro" > <xyz:echo-macro str="Hello World"/> <!-- this doesn't auto-complete --> </target> </project>

153872: When hovering over attribute/element names, we should show hover information containing the description for that element/attribute (much like we do on the Extensions page). Hovering over a translated attribute should show the substituted value for that attribute from the properties file. Hovering over an extension point ID should show the description for that extension. Hovering over a manifest header should show the javadoc for that header.
96227: N20050521-0010 If the status that's being passed to openError has a low-level exception then this exception's message should be displayed by the error dialog. Bug 96185 reports a problem with "out of disk space". In that scenario a ResourceException with a status that contains the low-level IOException is passed as argument and hence IOE's "out of disk" message gets lost. The dialog should either show this directly or by pressing the "Details" button. I'm marking this one as major since it can hide very important low-level messages. I also added workaround to the AbstractTextEditor: for now we append the low-level message to our main message.

85579: When the launch view reveives a CREATE event for a debug target or thread, it performs an "insert" with the new element. This will add the element to the end of the parents children which may be the incorrect order (there is no sorter in the view, but the debug model controls sorting of debug elements). We should instead perform a refresh on the newly created element.

98872: The AntDebugState incorrectly assumes that target names will be unique. They are unique per project but subbuilds introduce multiple projects and therefore target name collisions can occur. This results in incorrect stack representation for target dependencies for the subbuild. For example with a breakpoint on line 6 of antBuildFile.xml the stack looks like: Thread [Ant Build] (Suspended) depends: echo line: 6 default line: 2 default: ant line: 12 default line: 2 ===callExternal.xml==== <project name="internalProject" default="entry"> <target name="entry" depends="default"> <echo>entry</echo> </target> <target name="default"> <echo>default</echo> <ant antfile="antBuildFile.xml"></ant> </target> </project> =====antBuildFile.xml===== <project name="externalProject" default="default"> <target name="default" depends="depends"> <echo>default</echo> </target> <target name="depends"> <echo>depends!</echo> </target> </project>

89926: I am using some ant tasks that load native libraries. The directory were those libraries are is listed in the PATH environment variable. When launching ant from outside eclipse it works fine, but when launching it from inside eclipse with the "Set Input Handler" box checked it wonÂ´t find the libraries. Unchecking the box everything works fine. I have tracked down the issue to the following code inside the method "generateVMArguments" of the class "org.eclipse.ant.internal.ui.launchConfigurations": if (setInputHandler) { String swtLocation= getSWTLibraryLocation(); if (swtLocation != null) { vmArgs.append(" -Djava.library.path=\""); //$NON-NLS-1$ vmArgs.append(swtLocation); vmArgs.append('\"'); } } I think it would be better to append to the library path being used by the platform: vmArgs.append(" -Djava.library.path=\""); vmArgs.append(System.getProperty("java.library.path")); vmArgs.append(File.pathSeparator); vmArgs.append(swtLocation); vmArgs.append("\""); I have not tested this.

85590: I20050215-2300. The native widget used by List (and Table and Tree) on Linux-GTK supports typeahead via a floating entry, which can be triggered using Ctrl-F, or by simply typing in the list on newer versions of GTK+. Using this typeahead feature, single-selection lists can lose their selection when the user types in a prefix that is not found in the list. When this occurs, a selection event is sent, and the current index in the List is -1. This causes an IndexOutOfBoundsException in the Ant preference page when typing in the "Ant Color Options:" list. The cause is this code in AntPreferencePage which does not check for -1: private void handleAppearanceColorListSelection() { int i= fConsoleColorList.getSelectionIndex(); String key= fAppearanceColorListModel[i][1];
104047: The XML produced by the DialogSettings.save() method is not correct. If multiple arrayItems exist, every element after the first will have an extra "value" attribute. Here is a code snipet to illustrate: IDialogSettings export = new DialogSettings("Example"); String[] values1 = { "value1", "value2" }; export.put("key1", values1 ); String[] values2 = { "value3", "value4" }; export.put("key2", values2 ); try { export.save("C:\\test.xml"); } catch (IOException e) { // Do Nothing } The output of this is: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <section name="Example"> <list key="key1"> <item value="value1"/> <item value="value2"/> </list> <list key="key2" value="value2"> <item value="value3"/> <item value="value4"/> </list> </section> As you can see, the second "list" has an attribute "value" which it shouldn't. The reason is the value from the previous list element is not cleared before writing the second element. I.E. "value2" from the first list element is used as the value attribute for the second list element. Suggested fix: In DialogSettings.save(), add another "attributes.clear();" for the loop that iterates over the aarryItems field.
116028: When multiple fields are declared in a single statement, annotations are only applied to the first of them. Compare the behavior of the following program when compiled with javac and with the JDT compiler. import java.lang.reflect.*; import java.lang.annotation.*; public class Foo { @Deprecated public static Object x, y, z; public static void main(String[] args) throws Throwable { Class c = Foo.class; for (Field f : c.getFields()) { System.out.println(f.getName()); for (Annotation a : f.getDeclaredAnnotations()) { System.out.println(" " + a); } } } }

89055: ReferenceMap is used to cache objects from the extension registry using soft references. It stores these objects with Integer keys in an array of Entry objects. The Entry object then contains the Reference object. The Entry and Reference objects can be collapsed into a single object, and the keys could be made into int primitives instead of Integers. This will make the footprint smaller, and accesses to the cache will be slightly faster since Integer instances don't need to be created. I will investigate...
94402: If a composite operation is disposed, it should dispose all of its children. If a child of a composite operation is removed before the composite is disposed, it should dispose the removed operation. This should be documented.
90043: If the calling bundle does not have the necessary NetPermission. This is because a URL is constructed by the frameowrk with a stream handler specified. This code needs the proper doPrivileged calls to isolate the caller.
94401: When exporting a feature to an archive, the option to generate a jnlp file should not be selectable, since the resulting archive won't contain the file. The problem comes from the fact that the generated file is not listed as part of the root files to be copied.
133424: In I-20060327-0800, an API change was inadvertently introduced in IBuildEntry by renaming a static field SECONDARY_DEPENDENCIES to ADDITIONAL_BUNDLES. This change should be reverted. Also a @since 3.2 should be added to the field.
94400: In verifying bug #93192 for M7, I found this slight hole in the dispose strategy. It's not clear what should be done here. This is what happens after a successful undo: // Only add the operation to the redo stack if it can indeed be // redone. This conservatism is added to support the integration // of existing frameworks (such as Refactoring) that produce // undo and redo behavior on the fly and cannot guarantee that // a successful undo means a successful redo will be available. // We check this outside of the synchronized block. // See bug #84444 boolean addToRedoStack = operation.canRedo(); synchronized (undoRedoHistoryKey) { undoList.remove(operation); if (addToRedoStack && checkRedoLimit(operation)) { redoList.add(operation); } }
94406: 1. Enable view management in java perspective. 2. Launch a java debug session. Do not switch perspective when the debug session is suspended. This debug session opens the Variables View and Breakpoints View. 3. Teminate the debug session. 4. Launched a debug session in another langugage which opens other context- enabbled views. In my case, my debug session that opens the variables, breakpoints, memory, registers. 5. Terminate the debug session. Note that all views except the debug view are closed. 6. Launch the Java debug session again. This time, the variables and breakpoints views are not opened. The views do not get opened again unless the workbench is restarted. Looking at the context definition my debug adapter, the Variables View and the Breakpoints View are included as part of a context that has the base debug context as its parent. Including these views in our own context causes the context-enabled views not to be opened for Java again. Cleint's context should not affect each other. i.e. my context should not affect the Java context.

90049: The implementation of Bundle#getHeaders method is not compliant for the following reasons: - Passing null to Bundle#getHeaders causes an NPE, it should attempt to use the default locale if null is passed. - If a properties resource is not found for the specified locale then the headers returned must strip the leading '%' chars off of the values. We currently do not strip the leading '%' off. Note you can still get the raw headers (including '%') by passing an empty string into Bundle#getHeaders.

108466: When running runtime workspace, EclipseClassLoader.getResources(String) returns duplicate results for files found in plugin jarfiles (i.e. jar files listed in manifest.mf Bundle-ClassPath: entry or plugin.xml <library/> element). Steps to reproduce 1. create plugin project 2. add a jar with "file.txt" entry to the project 3. add the jar to plugin runtime classpath using plugin manifest editor 4. update plugin classpath (make sure the jar got added to java build path) 5. add code that counts number of entries returned by getClass().getClassLoader().getResources("file.txt") 5. start eclipse application, see that getResources returns two entries Apparently, eclipse adds the jar on plugin's classpath twice -- as a regular OSGi classpath entry and as a development entry.
77072: If you have nested breakpoint groups set in the Breakpoints view, we can have some problems managing the expanded state. This is because the tree viewer maintains multiple levels of "expanded state" which we weren't managing. For example, 1. Get the view into a state where you have some breakpoints and two levels of groups showing. 2. Select Expand All. 3. Manually collapse all by clicking on the top level containers (the trick here is that the second level of containers will still say they're expanded after this point). 4. Remove a breakpoint by doubleclicking it in the ruler. 5. Everything expands again because all breakpoints say that their parents are expanded.
77073: Build 20041026 When a breakpoint is added, we should automatically expand the tree so that it is visible.
83748: Location site should be 'Install location' ('Location site' term is confusing - we leaked the implementation into the UI; we should simply call it 'Install location') Install location page should show up only if the user does not agree with the summary (that lists the install location picked by us). Make the current install location available via 'Change install location...' button or something (the idea is that the last page is the summary of selections, including the install location(s). If the user does not like it, he can change it but we should not show the list right away).

116095: We're using the CodeGeneration class to get stub method body. It appears that every time we make the call (thousands of times), the ListenerList would grow in size. Eventually this list grows so large that it becomes a performance issue for us while memory keeps increasing. In the ScopedPreferenceStore constructor, a new listener is added to the ProjecPreferences but I don't see it ever being removed. While the ListenerList attempts to check for duplicate listeners, the listener doesn't implement equals.
89044: It should be possible that the PDE junit test does not run from the UI thread. I am currently working with the abbot framework, which will afaik be integrated or supported by Eclipse later. Unfortunately since the entire test is running in the UI thread it is very hard or impossible to set up a fixture which opens a dialog (example: TestCase#setUp() should open a preference page, where my different tests work on and TestCase#tearDown() should close it). Since the open dialog blocks the UI thread (with the cosequence that the testMethods are called only when I close the dialog) there is currently no workaround other than opening the dialog within each test method which is afaik not the intention of unit tests. As a solution I would suggest that one can choose whether to run the junit tests from the UI thread when configuring the launch configuration. Some checkbox on the configuration tab would suffice... This would greatly simplifiying the task of abbot workbench tests.

After running Tomcat several times, there is a huge slow down in Tomcat: Almost all the CPU time (more than 80%) is allocated to a thread in Eclipse, Tomcat itself is not consuming much CPU time (less than 1%) but is not responding correctly at all.
