103832: The final OSGi R4 specification has added the following methods to the conditional permission admin spec. ConditionalPermissionAdmin: getConditionalPermissionInfo(String) setConditionalPermissionInfo(String, ConditionInfo[], PermissionInfo[]) ConditionalPermissionInfo: getName() The implementation needs to be updated accordingly.
94721: Since 3.0, when a classloader is created the manifest.mf of the jar put on the classloader is read in order to find the package information. It is to note that there is almost never any package information. In 3.0, because bundles were shipped in a directory, the inner jars almost never had any interesting information and loading the manifest them was not noticeable. In 3.1, where bundles are shipping as jars, the jar put on the classpath is the bundle jar itself, meaning that the manifest loaded if the manifest from the jar, which is usually bigger because of the information it has about import, export, etc. Because of jared bundle, the size of the manifest and the fact that the info we are loading the jar is almost never present, we should have a flag that remembers that no package info is available when a bundle has '.' on the classpath. This flag should be set at install time.
90362: What is the behaviour with #nodeExists w.r.t. persistence? For instance if you say #nodeExists to a scope root, should it return TRUE for all nodes in memory plus those on disk that it hasn't loaded yet? I think that we're OK for instance and config because we do the lazy loading. (#initializeChildren) We need to do the same for ProjectPreferences though.
110188: I20050920 We should provide a hook for completing inside string literals. Clients like APT could use this hook to propose valid strings in their context.
81409: From bug 80401: AbstractDecoratedTextEditor shows a 'Preferences...' action in both its context and ruler context menus. Once the preference page supports filtering, only a subset of 'interesting' pages will be displayed in the such opened preference dialog. You can change the set of pages by extending AbstractDecoratedTextEditor.collectContextMenuPreferencePages.

88031: I20050315-0800 When we open the preferences from the editors we only show some preference nodes. When the user now wants to change some other preference he has to close and reopen the preference dialog via Window > Preferences in order to get all preferences. There needs to be a way to show all preferences. A possible solution might be to use the filter field: make it read-only and show: "Filtered". Then the "Clear" button could be used to show all preferences.
90353: The last time I profiled switching perspectives, a large portion of the time was spent re-creating the presentation widgets. We could improve the time to switch perspectives by about 40% if we cached the widgets for the last 3 opened perspectives rather than destroying and recreating them every time.
132385: If you remove all the renderings for a monitor in the memory view, you are left with the select-a-rendering rendering. The "Remove Rendering" action in the toobar remains active despite not having any effect when clicked. I would expect it to be disabled once the select-a-rendering rendering is displayed.
102572: IDEA seems to support a kind of completion called CamelHumps. That is, you write NPE and it expands NullPointerException. This can be done for both classes and methods. Now, it seems useful and it seems to me that you've already implemented part of it in the "Find Type" dialog. See also the discussion thread that prompted me to ask for this enhancement: http://www.javalobby.org/java/forums/m91837410.html
101241: N20050622-0010 AFAIK, the plugin exporter currently builds a plugin's class files from scratch before it packages the whole plugin. What I request is an option to tell the pde exporter to build the plugin with the normal eclipse build mechanisms, and then take the contents of the output ("bin") folders to package the plugin. This would speed up plugin-exports quite a bit, and it would probably solve bug 66177 and bug 101229.
90357: Whenever possible, the workbench maintains the same active part when switching perspectives. However, the workbench still deactivates and reactives the active part during a perspective switch even if it ends up remianing unchanged. A large portion (about 30%) of the runtime for switching perspectives currently goes into recomputing commands, action sets, contribution items, etc. that occurs as a result of the activation change.
82729: Most of the actions that perform blocking operations on the debug model (resume, suspend, step, etc.) have been recently changed to run in a background thread. The "Run To Line" action should also be migrated.
77380: I20041101 As I move the cursor over hyperlinks in the stack trace console, the hyperlink text draws a pixel (or so?) higher than the underlying text, making the text appear as it is moving.
77386: Currently the URL for the Ant external doc is hardcoded. We should present a UI to allow the user to modify.

110186: This is split from bug 109979. On Unix platforms, removing the executable bit from a directory means that the directory contents can no longer be listed. In Eclipse, this is manifested by the children being deleted from the Eclipse workspace (Note: the children are NOT deleted from the file system). This can be very alarming for the user because it appears they have lost work. The property page that allows the executable bit to be changed should prompt for confirmation when it is changed on a directory (org.eclipse.ui.internal.ide.dialogs.ResourceInfoPage). Since the exact behaviour may vary across platforms, I suggest something like: "Removing the executable attribute from a folder may cause the contents of that folder to be unreadable, resulting in the appearance that those contents have been deleted. Are you sure you want to do this?"

88037: It seems that eclipse ant editor doesn't resolve imports whose file attribute contains variable references. An example follows, using two small buildfiles: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <project name="test1" basedir="."> <!-- This is file test1.ant.xml --> <target name="test1" description="--> description"> <echo>test1 target OK</echo> </target> </project> <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <project name="test2" basedir="."> <!-- This is file test2.ant.xml --> <import file="${dol.ant.tools.dir}/test/test1.ant.xml" /> <target name="test2" depends="test1"> <echo>test2 target OK</echo> </target> </project> The variable dol.ant.tools.dir is set up in Preference>Ant>Runtime to be ${workspace_loc:___EXT_AntTools} and test2.ant.xml is placed in ___EXT_AntTools/test, which is a dir in the current workspace (not a linked resource). Eclipse editor complains, at the point where the import appears, with a warning with the following pop-up text: Cannot find ${workspace_loc:___EXT_AntTools}/test/test1.ant.xml imported from D: \EclipseWorkspaces\3.1M5a-webtools\___EXT_AntTools\test\test2.ant.xml Moreover then complains with an error, at the line where target test2 begins, stating that "target test1 is not defined in this project". Removing the reference to ${dol.ant.tools.dir} and substituting it with the correct explicit path (either absolute or relative) solves the problem. This notwithstanding, ant itself works well. Target test2 can be launched and shows the expected behaviour. Thanks.

90389: 3.1M6, note that this is most visually apparent on motif - open a CVS Repositories view in the Resource perspective - connect to dev.eclipse.org - somewhat quickly: - begin retrieving the org.eclipse.swt project from HEAD - click "Run in Background" - switch to the Navigator view, and the org.eclipse.swt project will be there - expand its top level only, and its only folder child so far should be Eclipse SWT, which takes a while to travel from CVS - if you watch it you'll notice the tree flash a few times, though nothing visually changes in it (not even its vertical scrollbar) This is happening because WorkbenchContentProvider is invoking setRedraw(false) and then setRedraw(true) often without invoking any methods on Tree in between. This causes flash because the Tree needs to do a full redraw whenever it receives setRedraw(true); if nothing has happened since setRedraw(false) then this is an unnecessary redraw(), which is the cause of the flash. Is it possible for WorkbenchContentProvider to somehow determine the nature of the work it's going to do between the setRedraw() invocations and choose to not invoke setRedraw() if appropriate?

114521: We have a language that had a Win32 IDE and now Eclipse, since 2.x. Depending on the VM state, the color to be used to highlight the executing line changes. It could be green or blue or red or brown (actually, the 4 different modes can be customized via a pref page). This requirement of ours is an old one, see bug#33598 and bug#36068 for example. Now the 3.x stream has support to customize teh marker annotation used for teh highlighting. However, doing so is a lot more work than it should. We did it the hard way, and here's what was needed: 1) Copy/Paste of these dbg internal classes into my plugin: InstructionPointerAnnotation InstructionPointerContext InstructionPointerManager 2) Change InstructionPointerAnnotation's constructor to take teh marker type as parameter 3) Change InstructionPointerManager.addAnnotation so that first it asks the IStackFrame what the markerType should be (a String), and pass that to the constructor in step 2 above. (the more correct solution is to ask the debug model presentation) 4) In plugin.xml I define my 4 markers much like the debugger does for its default one. 5) In my FooBarDebugModelPresentation.addAnnotations I have to do this: com.foo.bar.debug.ui.workaround.InstructionPointerManager.getDefault ().addAnnotation(myEditor, myStackFrame); return true; 6) In FooBarDebugModelPresentation.removeAnnotations I have to do this: 7) com.foo.bar.debug.ui.workaround.InstructionPointerManager.getDefault ().removeAnnotations(myDebugTarget); Whil ethis works, it is too much work. I should not have needed to copy/paste existing internal method. My suggestion: the DBG platform should ask my debug model presentation for the marker type (string) to use for the Instruction Pointer. This way people only need to implement 1 method to override teh marker. In this method they can return any of the N markers they have for the different colors they may want to use depending on the VM state. The DBG core InstructionPointerManager.addAnnotation would ask me for this value first, and then call its InstructionPointerAnnotation's constructor passing this parameter, If I do not implement this method (do not implement the IWhatever interface) then you can use your current, existing default.
81428: Build 3.0M3 The symptoms are the J9 launching plug-in does not work in debug mode with this build. After snooping around, I discovered that the JDI code defines an *optional* default timeout argument in the class: org.eclipse.jdi.internal.connect.SocketListeningConnectorImpl see #defaultArguments() line:55 and then throws an expection if that argument is not provided #getConnectionArguments(Map) line:85 & 88 The J9 launching plug-in did not specify a timeout. The workaround is to change the J9 launching code to specify a timeout, then all seems to work ok.

81435: I200412160800 The Revert {Line, Block, Selection} actions in the ruler context menu are not correctly updated. This results in disabled menu entries and wrong behavior, as the actions cache the line of activity from the last isEnabled() call and operate on it when selected. Choosing "Revert ..." may change the document at the caret selection instead of at the line where the user invoked the context menu. The fix is to create two sets of actions: ruler based actions and selection based actions. The former are created on the fly when the context menu is created and compute their activity line based on the IVerticalRulerInfo obtained from the editor; the latter are part of AbstractDecoratedTextEditor's action set and operate based on the editor's selection. The selection based actions are used when the Revert actions are activated using keyboard shortcuts.
79117: From the Run or Debug dialog, if you provide a Main class name which has trailing white space, Eclipse attempts to load the class with that space in the name. This seems clearly the wrong thing to do. The best solution, I think, is to rewrite the string in the dialog with (leading and) trailing space chopped. Alternatively, the chopped string could be passed to the loader
103863: Currently, SWT layouts work like this: - Some event occurs in the app - Method X updates a set of widgets - Method X notifies the wigdet's layout of the change (by calling changed() and layout()) This prevents writing any black box object that knows how to update a set of wigdets without depending on where those wigdets are used. This is creating a severe maintnance problem within the Eclipse UI. If code modifies a widget, it needs to: 1. Know about every other piece of code that calls that widget's computeSize method. 2. Know which object to trigger a layout on. 3. Know when to trigger a layout. (Or when to defer and undefer layouts) Issue 1 creates very large (and complicated) update methods. Issue 2 means that the spaghetti code is always specific to a particular layout and cannot be reused. Even minor layout changes often require severe refactoring. Issue 3 is impossible to get right. In our world, everything is triggered by listeners. Even though the layout only needs to happen after the last listener has done its thing and control returns to the event loop, there is no way to know that "this will be the last change to this widget before control returns to the event loop". We work around this by heuristically batching updates together, and making individual update methods responsible for as many widgets as possible. Our current heuristics work well, but the code is extremely complicated and brittle. This PR requests the following: a. Provide a way to flag a widget as "changed", such that any dependant layout will be notified and triggered when control returns to the event loop. (The client code MUST NOT be responsible for calling layout(...) or setLayoutDeferred) b. Provide a "preferred size changed" listener, so that a widget can have its position managed by something other than its immediate parent (aka proxy controls). c. Provide a way for layouts to indicate whether a change to a particular child will affect their own preferred size. This will be needed for SWT to correctly compute the effects of a "changed" event. Not sure whether to flag as "blocker" or "enhancement". It is really an enhancement, but it is blocking further work on the Eclipse layouts. Flagging as major as a compromise. :-)

101215: In N20050622-0010. If, from an editor, I undo an action (such as a Java refactoring) that affected outside resources, I am told "Undoing {ACTION} affects elements outside of {RESOURCE}. Continue with undoing {ACTION}?" Yes will undo the change. No will remove the change from the Undo stack, replacing it with individual edits within the current editor. The few times that I've hit "No", what I've really meant is "Really? Let me check that out first." Unfortunately, hitting "No" is not undoable: I can't get back to the state where the refactoring is still on the undo stack and I still have the option to undo it. So I'd like a third option: Cancel will restore the state before the undo request was activated. That way, I could hit Cancel, figure out the extent of the change I'm undoing, and then decide to execute it anyway. Or not. Note that Cancel is actually equivalent to Undo > Yes > Redo, but I've never on the spur of the moment thought of that. Also, the buttons might need to be renamed. If "No" doesn't do what I expect, what would I by default make of "Yes / No / Cancel". Perhaps "Yes / Cancel Undo / Discard Change"?

114588: Build: I20051101-1204 I noticed while reviewing references to IResource.getRawLocation(), that there are three such references in InputPatchPage. All references look like this: patchFile.getRawLocation().toFile() The only difference between IResource.getLocation() and getRawLocation() is that getRawLocation does not resolve path variables. So if you have a link relative to variable FOO, getRawLocation will return a path like "FOO/some/path/file.txt". This is going to cause the file not to be found in the case above, because IPath.toFile() will just create a file system path with the unresolved variable name as the first segment. getLocation() should be used here instead. Also, callers should check for null when using either getLocation or getRawLocation, because they are specified to return null in some cases.

105635: A field declaration with a generic type and trailing brackets and multiple fragements does not parse correctly: e.g.: public java.util.List<Integer> i[],j,k; or public java.util.List<Integer> i,j[]; class T { public java.util.List<Integer> i,j[],k; void m() { i[0] = null; // OK but should not be j[0] = null; k[0] = null; // OK but should not be } } The parser considers the type common to all the fragments to be an array type. This does not happen if the common type is a primitive type or a non-generic reference type. It does happen no matter which fragment the brackets are on. One can see the error by looking at the resulting AST as well, though interestingly, the AST appears correct for the case above, but is clearly wrong for the case where the brackets are on j. I would try to debug this further, but the parser is table driven and I do not know where the files that create the tables are. Here is what I get from printing out the AST for some examples: TREES FOR class T { public java.util.List<Integer> i,j[]; } ECLIPSE AST 0) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.CompilationUnit 0 49 1) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.TypeDeclaration 0 49 2) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.SimpleName 6 1 3) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.FieldDeclaration 10 37 4) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.Modifier 10 6 5) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ArrayType 17 23 <--- should not be an array of parameterized type 6) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ParameterizedType 17 23 7) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.SimpleType 17 14 8) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.QualifiedName 17 14 9) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.QualifiedName 17 9 10) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.SimpleName 17 4 11) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.SimpleName 22 4 12) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.SimpleName 27 4 13) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.SimpleType 32 7 14) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.SimpleName 32 7 15) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.VariableDeclarationFragment 41 1 16) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.SimpleName 41 1 17) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.VariableDeclarationFragment 43 3 18) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.SimpleName 43 1 This one looks ok, but the type for j is still incorrectly an array type. 88899: There was a compilation error in ToggleBreakpointAdapter due to a change in an illegal internal reference to TypeInfoRequestor.
92902: Usign Build id: I20050426-1700, you can no longer launch an Eclipse or JUnit configuration with errors in the workspace. I get prompted and cick Yes but no launch occurs. Commenting out the error (I can't fix it as it is not in my code), allows me to launch.
79945: JarVerifier creates a buffer for each file it verifies. This can have a serious performance impact. Also, the buffer size is 4K. I suggest having the buffer done as a private static field (there is no concurrency during verification), and increase its size to 8k.
86236: I propose including the following enchancement into the Eclipse platform runtime: custom extension instantiation. Currently, extension is instantiated in the ConfigurationElement#createExecutableExtension using the default constructor. Since it can be convenient to provide custom extension instances (for example, plugin may pre-configure instance before returning it), I propose the following possible solution: 1. Declare interface public interface IExecutableExtensionFactory { public Object getExtensionInstance(); } 2. Add the following piece of code to the ConfigurationElement.createExecutableExtension(), just before the "return result;" (after handling IExecutableExtension interface case): if(result instanceof IExecutableExtensionFactory) { result = ((IExecutableExtensionFactory)result).getExtensionInstance(); } return result; For example, this can be used for integrating PicoContainer into the plugin. All extensions will be represented as components in the PicoContainer (that will be filled during bundle startup) and extension factory (that implements IExecutableExtensionFactory proposed above) will take component from the container and return them. The more detailed descripition located here: news://eclipse.org:119/cvd665$4g7$1@www.eclipse.org
92901: From bug 72977: "Please note that creating (and afterwards disposing) the information control manager for every single popup isn't efficient. The idea is to install it once on the subject control. Please consider fixing this on your part."
79949: The Console View is missing Ctrl+C in context menu item. The menu item "Copy" is present but the Ctrl+C is not there. Version 3.1.M3. Thanks, Gary.

The code for the test case is as follows: ******************TEST_CASE **************************************** import org.eclipse.jdt.core.compiler.IProblem; import org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.AST; import org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ASTNode; import org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ASTParser; import org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.CompilationUnit; import junit.framework.TestCase; public class ArrayInitializerTest extends TestCase { public void testASTParser() { String text = "{\"red\", \"yellow\"}"; ASTParser parser = ASTParser.newParser(AST.JLS3); parser.setKind(ASTParser.K_EXPRESSION); parser.setSource(text.toCharArray()); ASTNode node = parser.createAST(null); if (node instanceof CompilationUnit) { CompilationUnit compilationUnit = (CompilationUnit) node; IProblem[] problems = compilationUnit.getProblems(); StringBuffer buffer = new StringBuffer(); for (int i=0; i<problems.length; i++) { buffer.append("Problem = " + problems[i].getMessage()); } fail(buffer.toString()); } } }

92924: There is VM bug which assumes all class loaders have access to classes of the parent classloader. This forces us to always ask the boot classloader for all classes even though we know the boot classloader does not have the class we are looking for. There is another approach which should help remedy the problem. To summarize the idea: At the point just before a bundle class loader is going to throw a class not found exception, it gets the class call stack and finds the first class on the stack that is neither a class loader instance of an instance of Class (effectively, this is to ignore calls to ClassLoader.loadClass() and Class.forName() so we can find who called them). For the first non-ClassLoader/non-Class class found, it checks to see if the class' class loader is a bundle class loader. If it is, it throws the exception (i.e., the bundle gets strict class loading), if it is not, it delegates to the the parent class loader instead. This works around the bug where a class on the boot classpath uses the calling classloader to load another class from the boot classloader.

87586: When the LaunchViewContextManager is deciding which views it needs to close, it just looks at what views it has opened. It doesn't consider which perspectives a view was opened in. This can cause us to close more views than we really should. For example: 1. Debug to a breakpoint with view management turned on in the Java perspective. Debug-related views (Variables, Breakpoints, etc.) are automatically opened. 2. Switch to the Debug perspective and terminate the launch. 3. The views that were opened (Variables, Breakpoints, etc.) are automatically closed despite the fact that they weren't automatically opened in the Debug perspective (they are already open by default).

87583: Eclipse carefully restores every views and editors on startup. This offers a nice user experience, however this unfortunately makes eclipse very long to start since it has to restore all the views, editors, etc. causing many plug-ins to be activated (that probably in the UI thread). As part of the performance work, it may worth trying to restore the workbench context in the background, such that the workbench is displayed as fast as possible to the end user. This has the advantage that if a plug-in takes a day to startup you are not stuck waiting. Note that even if this will not necessarily gives clear improvements (probably no numbers will change) it will help the user experience in perceiving the startup as faster. CC'ing Nick since I submitted him the idea before.

78653: Eclipse compare support uses the content type by passing in both the filename and the stream for inspection. Unfortunately, it calls a version of the interface that never performs inspection if there is a filename present. Instead, it simply fails if the filename is not bound to a content type pattern. This means that content type defined by file inspection patterns does not work with base Eclipse compare support. We can explicitly call the file inspection interface directly from our own merge facade, but this does not work for Eclipse and CVS, so there is not point in doing that before this is fixed.
78652: When we define a hierarchy of types, e.g. text->xml->EMF->EMX for Aurora models, we would like to be able to bind a default EMF merge facility in order to prevent any merge from happening in text mode, which is usually fatal to EMF models. We have a more sophisticated editor for our EMX files, which allow for diagram merging etc. But if we happen to start a merge of an EMX artifact in a product like RAD, which includes EMF merge but not EMX merge support, then we would like the content type hierarchy to automatically load EMF merge instead of text merge, which is what happens today.

89303: There are several use cases where a help resource href needs to be resolved into a URL so that it can be manipulated (opened, shown in a browser etc.). This task is dependent on the help system plugged in. I have added two methods to IWorkbenchHelpSystem: resolve and unresolve. The former takes a String href and returns a resolved URL according to the active help system. The later takes a URL and returns the original href if the first part of the URL matches the base URL. The changes I made are backward-compatible in that AbstractHelpSystem has default implementations of the methods. Our own help implementation (DefaultHelpSystem) implements these methods in a non-trivial way. Please release the attached patch because Intro needs it in order to be able to embed help documents inside Intro pages.

79098: EnhancedForStatement declares a method public IVariableBinding resolveBinding(); This API method is out of character for statement nodes, which don't generally have bindings at all. It's not clear why it was added in the first place. The method is certainly superfluous; clients can simply call EnhancedForStatement.getParameter().resolveBinding() The EnhancedForStatement is one of the node types that is new for JLS3. This API method was introduced back in 3.0, but has never been implemented correctly (it has always returned null). We should delete this method from the API before 3.1 ships.

108618: Running the build on MacOS doesn't work because the rootclasspath property is making incorrect assumptions on the location of the JRE. The build.xml generated by the "eclipse.buildScript" ant task contain the following: <path id="path_bootclasspath"> <fileset dir="${java.home}/lib"> <include name="*.jar"/> </fileset> </path> but on MacOS it should be: <path id="path_bootclasspath"> <fileset dir="${java.home}/../Classes"> <include name="*.jar"/> </fileset> </path> To make it portable, the generated code should be: <condition property="dir_bootclasspath" value="${java.home}/../Classes"> <os family="mac"/> </condition> <property name="dir_bootclasspath" value="${java.home}/lib"/> <path id="path_bootclasspath"> <fileset dir="${dir_bootclasspath}"> <include name="*.jar"/> </fileset> </path> There's a workaround, see http://eclipse.techforge.com/index.php/article/188

We should only consider compilation problems with an error severity in this case: Example program: public class ExTest { /** * @param args */ public static void main(String[] args) { new ExTest().foo(); } public void foo() { new Runnable() { public void run() { throw new NullPointerException("BOOM"); } }.run(); } } stack trace: Thread [main] (Suspended (Non-externalized string literal; it should be followed by //$NON-NLS-<n>$)) ExTest$1.run() line: 23 ExTest.foo() line: 27 ExTest.main(String[]) line: 15

104245: The Javadoc for AST.newCompilationUnit contains the following second paragraph: "Note that the new compilation unit is not automatically made the root node of this AST. This must be done explicitly by calling setRoot." But there is no method setRoot, at least no such public method. In fact, the abstract syntax "tree" is actually a forest, because there can be multiple nodes without parents. And calling the getRoot method on a particular node will actually return the root of the tree in the forest to which that node belongs. To make a node the only root of the AST, one must only make every other node children or descendents of it. Two suggested changes: (1) remove the second paragraph from newCompilationUnit javadoc and (2) include some discussion of what the "root" of an AST is in the Javadoc for the AST type.

Column number are zero-based. * Return zero if it is beyond the valid range. * * @param position a 0-based character position, possibly * negative or out of range * @return the 0-based coloumn number, or <code>0</code> if the character * position does not correspond to a source line in the original * source file or if column number information is not known for this * compilation unit * @see ASTParser */ public int columnNumber(final int position); /** * Given a line number and column number return the corresponding * position in the original source string. * Returns 0 if no line number information is available for this * compilation unit or the requested line number is less than one. * Return the total size of the source string if <code>line</code> * is greater than the actual number lines in the unit. * Assume 0 for the column number if <code>column</code> is less than 0 * or return the position of the last character of the line if <code>column</code> * is beyond the legal range. * * @param line the one-based line number * @param column the zero-based column number. * @return the 0-based character position in the source string. * Return <code>0</code> if line/column number information is not known * for this compilation unit or the input are not valid. */ public int getPosition(int line, int column); These 2 new APIs are required to correctly implement com.sun.mirror.util.SourcePosition.SourcePostion.column() and allow the posting of markers based on SourcePosition.
97765: Intro framework allows for specifying a shared style that will be injected in all Intro pages. This shared style is specified in the implementation element of the config. We inject this shared style into all intro pages. However, this is too aggressive. There are usecases where the shared style can actually complicate the ease of the contribution. Usecase: contribute a page into a config, where the page has a style too similar to the original config. The framework injects the shared style at the topic of the style list of the page, but it is too hard to override that shared style if too many CSS attributes are similar with the shared. suggested solution: add an attribute to a page definition that allows for disabling of the the shared style. eg: <page style="pageStyle" include-shared-style="false" .... /> the flag indicates whether or not we need to inject the shared style, as opposed to the current behavior where we inject in each page by default.

58185: I have several old style BMP files. When I attempt to load them into an image eclipse runs out of memory. The problem appears to be that the WinBMPFileFormat class does not check the header of the file correctly before reading the image. In my case, I have a BMP file with the following header: 0x42 0x4d 0xca 0x00 0x00 0x00 0x00 0x00 0x00 0x00 0x4a 0x00 0x00 0x00 0xC0 0x00 0x00 0x00 0x10 0x00 0x10 0x00 0x01 0x00 0x04 0x00 Notice the 0x0c at offset 14. This indicates that the Bitmap info header is only 12 bytes long and not the 42 that is being assumed. This conforms to the BITMAPCOREHEADER. According to microsoft the information starting at offset 14 is either a BITMAPINFO or a BITMAPCOREINFO. The only way to tell the difference is to check the size. see: http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/default.asp?url=/library/en- us/gdi/bitmaps_7jaq.asp

107335: It seems that eclipse ant editor doesn't resolve eclipse variable references in properties defined in property files. This bug seems very similar to the bug 88037 with the requirement that the property must come from a property file. An example follows, using one property file and two small buildfiles: Property file "test.properties": test.import.location=${workspace_loc:test} This property file is registered as a global property file in the eclispe ant runtime preferences. Imported buildfile "ant-test-import.xml": <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!-- This is file ant-test-import.xml --> <project name="ant-test-import"> <target name="test-import"> <echo>test-import target OK</echo> </target> </project> Importing buildfile "ant-test.xml": <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!-- This is file ant-test.xml --> <project name="ant-test" default="test"> <import file="${test.import.location}/ant-test-import.xml"/> <target name="test" depends="test-import"> <echo>test target OK</echo> </target> </project> The ant editor complains at the line where the import is performed with the following pop-up text: Cannot find ${workspace_loc:test}/ant-test-import.xml imported from C:\Documents and Settings\mruzicka\workspace\test\ant-test.xml From the message it is clear that the editor sees the definition of the property in the property file but it doestn't attempt to expand the eclipse varible contained therein. Furthermore at the "test" target definition the editor reports the following error (apparently as a consequence of the previous warning): Target test-import does not exist in this project When the same property with the same value (ie. ${workspace_loc:test}) is defined as a global property in the eclipse ant runtime preferences the problem doesn't show up. Despite the ant editor warnings/errors everything works as expected when the ant build is run. Thanks.

83153: The target resolution from the depends attribute does not work properly when there are spaces in the depends attribute text. For example... <target name="createdb" depends="init, updateScripts" If I place my cursor on 'init' and 'Open Declaration' (F3) the cursor will jump to the 'init' target. However, if I try the same with 'updateScripts' it fails. If I change the text to the following... <target name="createdb" depends="init,updateScripts" both of the targets will now resolve. I tested the following combinations... <target name="createdb" depends=" init, updateScripts" <target name="createdb" depends="init ,updateScripts " <target name="createdb" depends=" init , updateScripts " and none of them work. All of the whitespace had to be removed to get all of them to resolve properly. (note, when they don't work, I do get a message in the status bar reading 'Current text selection does not resolve to an Ant reference'). Since Ant doesn't have a problem with whitespace in the depends attribute, I believe that the Eclipse Ant Editor should also ignore it.

96451: 1. In debug perspective, start a debug session that opens the Memory View by context. 2. Window->New Window 3. The new window will also have the Memory View opened. 4. Terminate the debug session. 5. Go back to the first window and select something from the Debug View. It will result in the following exception. The Memory View is handling selection events from the Debug View after it is disposed. The selection listener in the Memory View is leaked because it adds/removes selection listener from the selection service of the active workbench window. In the case when there are multiple windows, one of the listeners get left behind. 88838: Early on this was involved in scenarios where editors examined other operations. This is no longer used. Operation approvers generally apply to all contexts and are installed at the OperationHistory level. Until there is a concrete need for this API it should be removed. It is gratuitous at this point.

88864: 20050323 We store the Javadoc locations now stored in the classpath attribute (IClasspathAttribute). a JRE container can now return IClasspathEntries that have the Javadoc location set. Bug 88859 has beem filed for a constant in jdt.core for the javadoc attribute name. Until this is done: "javadoc_location" is the attribute name I choose It would be good if you could do this for M6 as otherwise users won't have any javadoc locations for JRE's anymore (the old store in our land is gone: released 20050323) You might also have to be aware of container update requests that contain changed javadoc locations.
79912: The Run... Dialog comes up far to big on most platforms. 1) setShellSize uses getShell().getDisplay().getBounds(); for maximum sizes. This is not correct for multiple monitor case. See Control.getMonitor(). 2) In resize, calculations are being made for the size of tabs but there is no knowledge of how much spacing appears between the text and the image etc. This calculation is quite meaningless. You should rely on TabFolder.computeSize to give the correct answer. 3) getInitializeSize is returning a very large number which is not based on the contents of the dialog and is too big on many platforms. I would just stick with the default provided by Window. 4) initializeBounds should call initializeSashForm before calling super.initializeBounds. Otherwise, SashForm assumes that all children have the same weight and this throws off the value calculated by the super. Having done this, there is no need to call ensureSelectionAreaWidth or resize (assuming the sash weights are calculated correctly - see point 5). 5) initializeSashForm should use computeSize to determine the optimal weights. Call computeSize on the two children that are on the left and the right of the SashForm and use these as the weights. This will give the ideal weighting. private void initializeSashForm() { if (getSashForm() != null) { IDialogSettings settings = getDialogSettings(); int[] sashWeights; int w1, w2; w1 = fLaunchConfigurationSelectionArea.computeSize(SWT.DEFAULT, SWT.DEFALT).x; w2 = fLaunchConfigurationEditArea.computeSize(SWT.DEFAULT, SWT.DEFAULT).x; sashWeights = new int[] {w1, w2}; getSashForm().setWeights(sashWeights); }

81322: i200412142000 (see related bug 81201) I don't know what is the intended behavior for the plugin registry view in face of dynamic changes to the set of installed plug-ins. With the current implementation, the PDE/UI view might choke trying to process change events as they come. The root of the problem here is the fact that change events are not batched, and they are sent after the fact. So listeners need to be careful and not make any assumptions about the state of the extension registry/framework when they are handling a single event. In the case of the plugin registry, the safest thing to do would be to just to discard all the information kept about the plug-in registry when an event comes and to schedule a job to rebuild it asynchronously. If another event comes, that job should be cancelled and rescheduled for later on. At some point, bundle events/registry change events will stop to come and the job will be able to rebuild the model. Or, as suggested by Pascal, PDE UI could stop using the IPluginRegistry API and provide the same information by processing the extension registry and the set of bundles available through its BundleContext. I believe this is in the plan for PDE to become a BDE sometime in the future.
79008: JFace includes constants for UI sizes in terms of dialog units. Using dialog units for button height has proved problematic on platforms such as the Mac and Linux/GTK+ where themes like to do really fancy buttons with lots of padding. For some background, see bug 68568, bug 73730, and bug 78925. We have stopped using IDialogConstants.BUTTON_HEIGHT in the platform UI code, so I would like to get it removed elsewhere. Attached is a patch to stop using it in the debug UI code.

(Commas are often included in the "Key Sequence" field's text.) Applications such as Microsoft Excel to interpret the comma as a field delimiter instead of as part of the intended text. Instead of reading four fields, Excel reads five fields with the fourth field being empty. OCCURS ON: version: 3.1M6 menu: Window > Preferences > General Keys > View (tab) > Export EXAMPLE: To save the "Ctrl-," (control-comma) key sequence in the *.csv Export file, Eclipse writes the string: Navigate,Previous,Ctrl+,,In Windows Eclipse should instead write: Navigate,Previous,"Ctrl+,",In Windows VAGUELY RELATED BUG REPORTS: 86843, 85708 comment #2. SEE ALSO: "Comma-separated values" (Wikipedia) <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comma-separated_values#MIME_Type> Describes comma-separated value format. Includes links to draft specification, and available open source csv file utilities. "Designing for CSV Output" (Microsoft) <http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/default.asp?url=/library/en- us/RSCREATE/htm/rcr_creating_dc_v1_10j8.asp> (First list of bullet points describes what Ms. believes *.csv files should look like.) NOTE: On this page Ms. claims its *.csv files are MIME type: text/plain; this differs from most other descriptions of *.csv files seen on the web. "CSV Standard File Format" (Edoceo) <http://www.edoceo.com/utilis/csv-file-format.php> More human readable than the Microsoft page (despite typos). Includes examples, the last one is the most relevant to this bug report.

95987: 3.1m6 and m7. In the example below, GUI and library plugins are used. However, this appears general and would apply to situations which only use UI plugins. I created some a which depends on version 2 of a library plugin. The library plugin is marked singleton. Install the view and library into eclipse and show the view. All is good. Close eclipse. Install version 3 of library (also marked singleton) and run Eclipse (using -clean, of course). View is no longer available and get error about not being able to restore layout. This is BAD for any sort of enterprise situation -- something working fine is BROKEN merely by adding a new version of a plugin. It means that plugins CANNOT be specific about versions of dependencies if those dependencies are singleton (which is all UI plugins). Since nothing else is using the library plugin at all (or at least not version 3 specifically), my view ought to be able to resolve against and use version 2 of the library plugin!

131032: I added a new extension to org.eclipse.debug.ui.BreakpointOrganizers. In the breakpoint view, if I don't show my breakpoint organizer view and shut down the eclipse, i will get the null pointer exception. I found what will cause this problem. At first of starting eclipse, the DebugUIPlugin is loaded and stored all BreakpointOrganizers extensions(including my extension). When this plugin is shut down, it will dispose all added BreakpointOrganizers extensions. The problem is my plugin must be shutted down before DebugUIPlugin shut down. When DebugUIPlugin were trying to dispose all BreakpointOrganizers extensions, it will create this extension first and then call its dispose method if its delegate is not created. For example, i haven't active my breakpoint organizer view in Breakpoint View, so its delegate haven't created. When I closed the eclipse, DebugUIPlugin will try to create it first, but my plugin is already closed. Then "no class found" exception will be occurred. The problem is that Debug UI Plugin must be shutted down after my plugin and the Debug UI Plugin has loaded my plugin breakpoint organizer extension at start up. When the Debug UI plugin is shutting down, this will cause exception if my extension hasn't been created.
90293: In the PreferenceForwarder we pass along all API calls to the corresponding node in the preference node hierarchy. In all cases this means that the node will be loaded if it hasn't been already. In AbstractUIPlugin#shutdown they are calling #savePluginPreferences which creates the preference forwarder (if the preferences haven't been accessed before) and then calls #save. This in turn calls #flush on the node in the hierarchy. In all cases EXCEPT #flush we don't have to check but in the #flush case, we should do a no-op if the node doesn't exist in the node hierarchy. Otherwise the node will be loaded on shutdown in order to do a no-op.
107360: A bundle has the following Eclipse-AutoStart header: Eclipse-AutoStart: true; exceptions="org.eclipse.foo" While shutting down the framework the bundles are stopped. If a class from org.eclipse.foo package is loaded after the bundle has stopped then a CNFE is thrown because we do not restart bundles once the framework starts shutting down. The code should check to see if the package is really an autostart package before checking to see if the bundle has be stopped from shutting down the framework. This becomes important if a bundle has code which is used for a VM shutdown hook. This code should be included in an exceptions package to prevent the bundle from auto-starting when a class is loaded from that package.
79022: JFace includes constants for UI sizes in terms of dialog units. Using dialog units for button height has proved problematic on platforms such as the Mac and Linux/GTK+ where themes like to do really fancy buttons with lots of padding. For some background, see bug 68568, bug 73730, and bug 78925. We have stopped using IDialogConstants.BUTTON_HEIGHT in the platform UI code, so I would like to get it removed elsewhere. Attached is a patch to stop using it in the update code.

Expected: "o= new HashMap<?, ?>[0]" Maybe related to the error in the JLS3 grammar (15.10 Array Creation Expressions), which would not allow wildcards as type arguments there.
93319: I20050426-1700, GTK+ 2.6.4, KDE 3.3.2, Linux 2.6.11, X.org 6.8.2 It is possible to get Eclipse into a state where the editor tabs continue to switch, in some kind of a loop. It is possible to switch perspectives and open menus when in this state; the editors will keep switching. Typing in the console view will eventually cause it to stop. (There is a slight delay; be patient.) STEPS TO REPRODUCE: ------------------ 1.) Open four editors, and make sure Eclipse is big enough to show all the tabs. 2.) Select the right-most editor. 3.) Press "Ctrl+PageUp" three times really fast Assume the editors were named A, B, C, D, and D was selected first. Eclipse will switch to editor C, B and then A. At this point, Eclipse should stop. However, the cycle continues -- selecting this same group of editors in the same order over again. Try different combinations! It's fun!

92015: IDEWorkbenchWindowAdvisor updates the window title whenever the most common events are fired from the workbench page (open + close events, part activation, parts brought to top, etc.). Running OptimizeIt, I found that 5% of the CPU time was spent inside the advisor's handler for the broughtToTop event when switching between the Java and Debug perspectives with no editors open. (I didn't measure the time spent in the advisor's other methods). The advisor computes the window title as a function of the active editor and active page. It should remember the previously active editor + page and avoid recomputing the title if they are unchanged. It should also avoid sending a new title to the configurer if the new title is exactly the same as the old one.
92012: Using code in HEAD on april 18 (probably reproducable using any recent build as well). Enable the following debug logging options for org.eclipse.ui: debug listeners listeners/IWorkbenchPage.IPartListener2 Create 2 perspectives containing detached views. Switch between them. Notice that an activate event is fired for each detached view in the perspective on every perspective switch. This is a performance problem because part activation is quite slow.

100782: XHTML model finder api had a glitch.... /* * Util method similar to DOM getElementById() method, but it works without * an id attribute being specified. Deep searches all children in this * container's DOM for the first child with the given id. The element * retrieved must have the passed local name. Note that in an XHTML file * (aka DOM) elements should have a unique id within the scope of a * document. We use local name because this allows for finding intro * anchors, includes and dynamic content element regardless of whether or * not an xmlns was used in the xml. */ public static Element getElementById(Document dom, String id, String localElementName) { NodeList children = dom.getElementsByTagNameNS("*", "*"); //$NON-NLS-1$ for (int i = 0; i < children.getLength(); i++) { Element element = (Element) children.item(i); if (element.getAttribute("id").equals(id)) //$NON-NLS-1$ return element; } // non found. return null; } Above method has a glitch where we use * as opposed to the the actual element name.

103810: 3.1 As per bug 103379, site objects should release their reference to the part when the part is disposed. This applies for both regular workbench parts (PartSite), nested parts (MultiPageEditorSite), and pages within parts (PageSite). Currently parts are disposed after the site (see ViewReference.doDisposePart and EditorReference.doDisposePart). However, the site and all its services should remain in effect until after the part has been disposed.
93378: From 80401: I noticed that if "Insert spaces for tabs when typing" is selected on the Ant Editor preferences, then, changing the tab width in the general Text Editors preferences does not take effect until you shut down any open editors and re-open them. I'm assuming this is a bug related to this migration. I'm using 3.1M5a. Doing a stopTabConversion(), followed by a startTabConversion() in the handlePreferenceStoreChanged() method of the editor (when the tab width changes), fixes this. You just need to reconfigure the TabConverter to uses the new width, so I guess this would work too: if (fTabConverter != null) { fTabConverter.setNumberOfSpacesPerTab(getTabSize()); }

85750: Since the Packages Explorer shows working sets, it would be benefitial to adapt working sets to ResourceMappings so that Team operations can appear on working sets. Here are the changes that are contained in the attached patches: 1) Added an adapter factory to IDE that adapts IWorkingSet to IContributorResourceAdapter and ResourceMapping 2) Added another adapter from IWorkingSet to IWorkbenchAdapter so generic UI can get the name and image of the working set. This could be in Workbenh but I added it to IDE since I already had an adapter factory there. 3) Modified the project persistent property tester to support the display of the Team menu on a working set that contains projects of one repository type allong with some unshared projects. The TEam menu will not appear if there are no shared projects or projects mapped to two different repositories. 4) Modified the getAdapter method of WorkingSet to defer to the adapter manager.
80063: i20041201 Code assist allows overriding super class private method. Superclass' private members should be omitted instead. Example: class A { private void m1() {} } class B extends A { } Triggering code assist inside B's body will offer to "override" A's m1() method, which is private and cannot be overriden, resulting in: class A { private void m1() {} } class B extends A { private void m1() {} } Where B's m1 method is completely unrelated to A's m1 method. The resulting code is valid but it is not what the developer intended (which was to override a super class' method).

109104: Build: I20050906-1200 Several times while using this build, I have hit save in an editor but the buffer contents have not been flushed to disk. When this happens, the file on disk has the same contents as the previous save, but the "Save" action is greyed out and the dirty indicator (*) is gone from the editor tab. There are no errors in the log file or on the Java console. The first couple of times this happened, I thought it was an error in the debugger because my breakpoints and stepping were not lining up with the correct code. However, it just happened again, and I opened the same file in Wordpad to discover that the editor contents do not match the contents in Wordpad. Each time this happened, dirtying the editor again and hitting save again would flush the correct contents to disk. I have not been able to reproduce it consistently, but here is what I did the most recent time it happened. 1) Did a search and replace in a Java file (Ctrl+F, Replace All) 2) Hit save. 3) Discovered that I replaced with the wrong thing 4) Hit Undo (Ctrl+Z) 5) Did another search and replace with the correct value 6) Hit Save. The editor now looks correct, but the file on disk still looks like it was in step 2). I will attach a screen shot in case it helps clarify.

79068: need option to control line wrapping before/after operators It would be nice if there was a code formatting option (that could ideally be referenced by the wrap java strings feature of the java editor), to set wrapping before or after operators. One example of where this option would apply is when formatting code that looks like this: if (a.getSomeBooleanValue() && b.getSomeOtherBooleanValue() && c.getYetAnotherBooleanValue()) { doSomething(); } The code formatter currently always changes the code above to the code below, and there's no option (at least not that I've found) to control this behavior. if (a.getSomeBooleanValue() && b.getSomeOtherBooleanValue() && c.getYetAnotherBooleanValue()) { doSomething(); } Note also that the wrap java strings feature and the code formatter are inconsistent with respect to this behavior. Specifically, if I use the wrap java strings feature, I get this: System.out.println("asdlfj asfl;kj saflksj fl;ksaj flsjd f;asl fsjdf" + "sdflkjsdfl;jaslfdjsdlfkj sdflk sdjflks f"); Now, when I format the code using the code formatter, I get System.out.println("asdlfj asfl;kj saflksj fl;ksaj flsjd f;asl fsjdf" + "sdflkjsdfl;jaslfdjsdlfkj sdflk sdjflks f"); Note that one wraps before the + operator and the other wraps after the plus operator (not to mention the inconsistent indentation).

80059: For 3.1 we want to have all Elcipse RCP plugins using only the JCL Foundation class library. In general there are very few types of changes needed to do this. Below is a list of the kinds of changes and some examples of where they occur for JFace. - Boolean.valueOf(boolean) : easily replaced. Used in - Action - Use of javax.xml.transform : classes in this package are used in DialogSettings.save to write out the settings. There are several copies of XMLWriter in the platform (resources, JDT and PDE all have them). XMLWriter is a helper that does effective quoting etc. In the case of DialogSettings.save you have a document so the approach should be to traverse the document and call methods on an XMLWriter. - String.split()/.matches : easily replaced. Used in - StringConverter

80053: For 3.1 we want to have all Elcipse RCP plugins using only the JCL Foundation class library. In general there are very few types of changes needed to do this. Below is a list of the kinds of changes and some examples of where they occur. - Use of javax.xml.transform : classes in this package are used in XMLMemento.save to write out the memento. There are several copies of XMLWriter in the platform (resources, JDT and PDE all have them). XMLWriter is a helper that does effective quoting etc. In the case fo XMLMemento.save you have a document so the approach should be to traverse the document and call methods on an XMLWriter. - java.nio.charset : classes in here used in WorkbenchEncoding ot get Charset.isSupported() and IllegalCharsetNameException. Replacements are unclear. - Nested expections : Foundation's Throwable does not have a constructor that takes a nested throwables. The fix is obviously to remove the nesting but this will eliminate some information. We may instead elect to introduce a subclass which does have the nesting support. Affected areas: - XMLMemento - CommandException - ContextException - java.util.regex : Not sure what the replacement strategy would be. Used in - IActivityPatternBinding - java.util.Bitset.nextBitSet() and .clear() : used in WorkbenchPartReference. Change is unclear but likely not hard. - Boolean.valueOf(boolean) : easily replaced. Used in - WorkbenchWindow - String.split() : easily replaced. Used in - ConfigurationLogDefaultSection

88128: We are trying to port legacy runtime environments onto the Eclipse platform. Some of these environments use JVM shutdown hooks that perform some amount of cleanup. Unfortunately, in an Eclipse environment the bundles are stopped before the shutdown hooks are executed, which severely restricts what can be done in the hook. For example, no classes may be loaded. In general, we do not own the code for the hooks, so we cannot easily change the code to fit some other mechanism (e.g. bundle start levels). We can, however, live without a standard shutdown of the Eclipse platform. That is, if bundles stayed active during the JVM shutdown, I believe that would be acceptable. Here is a very trivial example. If you run it, you should get the following output: osgi> ### adding shutdown hook ### in shutdown hook com.acme.Main$ShutdownHook java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: com/acme/Foo at com.acme.Main$ShutdownHook.run(Main.java:16) -------------- main application ----------- package com.acme; import org.eclipse.core.runtime.IPlatformRunnable; public class Main implements IPlatformRunnable { public Object run(Object arg0) throws Exception { System.out.println("### adding shutdown hook"); Runtime.getRuntime().addShutdownHook(new ShutdownHook()); return null; } private static class ShutdownHook extends Thread { public void run() { System.out.println("### in shutdown hook " + this.getClass().getName()); Foo f = new Foo(); } } } --------------- auxiliary class Foo -------------------- package com.acme; public class Foo { } -------------- plugin.xml ----------------------- <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <?eclipse version="3.0"?> <plugin> <extension id="Test" point="org.eclipse.core.runtime.applications"> <application> <run class="com.acme.Main"/> </application> </extension> </plugin> ------------------ manifest.mf ---------------- Manifest-Version: 1.0 Bundle-Name: Sample Bundle Bundle-SymbolicName: com.bugsrus Bundle-Version: 1.0.0 Bundle-ClassPath: testbundle.jar Bundle-Vendor: Acme Corp. Bundle-Localization: plugin Eclipse-AutoStart: true Import-Package: org.eclipse.core.runtime, org.osgi.framework

89475: I20050329 Consider this example: ------------- snip ----------- package folding; public interface AdjacentRegions { /** * comment 1 */ /** * comment 2 */ void foo(); } ----------------------------------- - fold both comments (State A) - select the entire first line, including the line delimiter at its end - unfold the second comment > expected: the second comment is not selected at all < actual: the first line (folded part) of the second comment is selected - return to State A - select the entire second line, including the delimiter at its end - unfold the first comment > expected: the first comment is not selected at all < actual: the last line (folded part) of the first comment is selected The current behavior is counterintuitive. The critical point is regions that are folded away exactly at the borders of the selection. The intuitive solution is to include such regions exactly if they belong to a ProjectionAnnotation that overlaps with the selection. The solution is to check the ProjectionAnnotationModel in ProjectionViewer.widgetSelection2ModelSelection.
88144: On GTK+, toolbars do not wrap. Instead, they are just clipped if the view gets too thin to support the toolbar. This issue is tracked in bug 46025. However, all three of the bugs filed about this issue are because of the toolbar for the synchronize view. This toolbar has the largest set of buttons of any in the eclipse SDK (I checked them all). Here are the top 5: Buttons Separators View ======================================== 12 4 Synchronize 10 2 Debug 9 2 Breakpoints 6 2 CVS Repositories 6 1 Classic Search However, of these, both the Debug and Breakpoints views get half of the screen in their default layout for the Debug perspective. The CVS Repositories view is also significantly wider in its default layout in the CVS Repository Exploring perspective. Maybe the number of toolbar buttons should be reduced? The view's toolbar is quite well populated. Or, maybe it should be given a wider default width in its perspective. As it is, this is a usability problem on Linux-GTK+, and I would argue that the sheer number of toolbar buttons may be a usability problem itself.

88131: I have done some work in the framework to enable it to use ReliableFiles to store framework critical data. I've been working with Tom W. on the architecture of this and am now ready to submit the work to Eclipse. Overview: The eclipse framework has a implementation of ReliableFile that does a couple things: manages the input and output streams to be synchronized, appends a checksum to the file to ensure data is valid, and keeps a fallback version of the file in case of original file corruption. This propsal makes the framework configuration file ".bundledata" a reliable file. Also the framework FileManager files, ".manager/.fileTable" are also made reliable files. Details: ReliableFile originally used a file nameing scheme of [file].tmp -> [file].new -> [file] -> [file.bak]. .bundledata is a framework file that is managed by FileManager which makes uses the naming convention [file].1 -> [file].2 -> .... [file].[n]. Since .bundledata is potentially shared among multiple eclipse instances, it must remain managed by filemanager. So, ReliableFile was modified to use the FileManager naming scheme and now is: [file].tmp -> [file].[n+1] where n+1 is the next generation. ReliableFile was also enhanced to allow cooperative file naming with another file manger (i.e. FileManager). FileManager was enhanced to use ReliableFile to save ".manager/.fileTable". This helps ensure that a usable version of .fileTable is available as loosing this file results in the loss of all FileManager managed files. FileManager was also enhanced to provide a managed InputStream and OutputStream for an application. This is only useful for managing a single file that does not need to have it's file writes and FileManger.update() done atomically for a set of 2 or more files. This managed input/output stream is by default a standard FileInput/OutputStream and optinally a ReliableFileInput/OutputStream via a System property. For eRCP (embedded RCP), the ReliableFile streams would be enabled by default. These managed streams has some of the following advantages: consistent file update sequences (i.e. write to tmp file, flush stream, sync stream, update filemangaer, keep backupfile), the actual stream type is transparent to a filemanager client, simplifies client file writes, provides the ability to undo (abort) file updates if problems occur (e.g. disk full). Code to follow... TBC

82833: Version: 3.1.0 Build id: I20050112-1200 When i execute a task that fails with a build exception the stack trace it generates does not show in the eclipse console. If you run the command line version of ant with a -v option it prints the stacktrace to stderr. The stacktrace can be VERY useful for debugging tasks that have useless build exception messages. The default ant logger will print a stack trace in buildFinished if the exception is not a BuildException or the logging level is verbose. This should only require a trivial change to RemoteAntBuildLogger.

102440: StructuredViewer.java: public void update(Object[] elements, String[] properties) { for (int i = 0; i < elements.length; ++i) update(elements[i], properties); } This loops through all the elements fed to it, which calls update(Object element, String[] properties) which calls internalUpdate(Widget widget, Object element, String[] properties) which checks the properties with the filter&sorter: if (needsRefilter) { refresh(); return; } And if successful a full refresh has been done, yet update() is still looping over more elements to update. The full refresh gets/filters/sorts _all_ the elements as far as I understand it. There is no need to continue. Updating with an Object[] of 1000 elements that triggers the refresh() on the first element need not call update() on the remaining 999 elements. They could theoretically be 999 elements that trigger a refresh() (resulting in a bogged down gui thread..)
90480: In order to overcome some VM bugs and to address some backwards compatibility issues OSGi R4 will introduce a new framework property (org.osgi.framework.bootdelegation) This property is used to specify a comma separated list of package prefixes that must always be delegated to the parent classloader. There is a bug in the reference VM implementation that assumes that all classloaders have access to the sun.* packages available on the boot classpath. If we restrict access to this package from the bundle classloaders then things can start to fail. For example, reflection will start to fail with NoClassDefFoundErrors when trying to load sun.* classes. In order to overcome this bug one could specify the following property. -Dorg.osgi.framework.bootdelegation="sun.,com.sun." This whould force all classes from sun.* and com.sun.* to be delegated to the parent first. The framework does simple startsWith to determine if the class should be delegated to the parent. If you desire to delegate all resource requests to the parent classloader then you specify the empty string. -Dorg.osgi.framework.bootdelegation="" This will give you the same behavior as Eclipse 3.0 where all resource requests were delegated to the parent first. For Eclipse 3.1 the we should set this property to the empty string if it is not already set to give us the same symatics as Eclispe 3.0 WRT parent delegation.

For example, only one instance of "my-classpath-container" will be included on runtime classpath when launching from "project2" of the following workspace /project1 /my-classpath-container /project2 (depends on project1) /my-classpath-container The problem seems to be caused by wrong project passed to ClasspathContainerInitializer#getComparisonID from DefaultProjectClasspathEntry#expandProject. In my example, project2 will be used regardless of origin of classpath container entry. I will attach proposed fix shortly.
81529: I experimented with a shared string pool class in the runtime plugin. This currently has some experimental API hanging out, and a non-API hook to add string sharing participants. Resources plugin is using this non-API internal hook. I should yank all of this out of runtime and move it into non-API land in the resources plugin. Pending experiments with VM-level interning we way decide to expose it again later.
82865: * The breakpoints view "Show >" cascade menu should be sorted alphabetically. However, I think the standard "Breakpoints" choice should be first (flat list), and the "Advanced..." item should be last. * The menus should "check" the currently selected presentation.

82862: Build: I20050112 I did some analysis of the strings in the Java heap after opening Eclipse with an empty workspace in the resource perspective. The most duplicated string is "bundleentry", which appears 141 times for a total of 9240 bytes of used heap space. I tracked this down to AbstractBundleData, which builds up a string representing a bundle URL, and then passes this string to the URL constructor. The constructor then parses the string to obtain the various parts (protocol, host, port, etc). By directly calling the URL constructor that takes all these parts as separate strings, we can eliminate this duplication since the identical string can be used as the protocol value for all URLs.
110076: The UndoActionHandler and RedoActionHandler have some small nits. Looking at source, PropertySheetEntry.getEditor (Composite parent), it calls: setErrorText (editor.getErrorMessage ()) It should call: setErrorText (MessageFormat.format (editor.getErrorMessage (), new Object[] {editValue})); (similar to how error message is set in TextCellEditor.editOccured(ModifyEvent e))
132266: During classpath computation, a host goes on a fragment's classpath. But a fragment does not go on its host's classpath. While this is not what happens at runtime, PDE enforces this good modular programming since it is recommended to be agnostic from its fragments. Fragments can and go. This however seems to be restrictive for some scenarios. So we will enable this circular dependency option via a system property, since we don't want to encourage the general population to start making those kinds of dependencies. Circular dependencies cause problems with pde/build etc.. The functionality will be enabled when Eclipse is launched with -Dpde.allowCycles=true
90475: Currently Dynamic Imports are bound before looking for a package in required bundles or the local classloader. In OSGi R4 Dynamic Imports should be bound after we have exhausted the OSGi delegation model (imported packages, required bundles, private classloader).

82854: Build: I20050112 I am analyzing the heap usage for an instance of the workbench - platform only, empty workspace. Many of the allocations point to KeySequenceBindingNode. In particular, it seems to store quadruply-nested HashMaps. It might be worth coding a custom data structure to reduce the memory footprint. Here are some of the objects currently allocated by command-related objects (object name and the number of instances of that object allocated by command objects): Object[] - 3816 HashMap$Entry - 3379 HashMap - 2543 ArrayList - 861 TreeMap$Entry - 969 Integer - 331 HashSet - 471 Collections$UnmodifiableRandomAccessList - 631 KeySequence - 549 TreeMap - 534 TreeMap$1 - 93 TreeSet - 527 KeySequenceBindingDefinition - 457 Collections$UnmodifiableSortedSet - 436 KeyStroke - 435 CommandDefinition - 362 HashMap$Values - 273 HashMap$EntrySet - 270 KeySequenceBindingNode - 270 HashMap$KeySet - 95 The grand total of this list is 17,302 objects. This doesn't include any strings and char[] objects that must also be stored here. Clearly a specialized data structure is required to get the necessary performance on key sequence lookups, but there is certainly room for improvement here.

106803: Hi, I think I've got a bug on my hands. When I launch an Ant file in my project, it is not receiving the correct working directory. I looked at my JRE preferences for the launch, and I have ensured that the Ant build file is launching in a seperate JRE. The Ant build file says it is using the default working directory (ProjectA/build) which is the directory it is located in (but greyed out to imply the user does not need to set this). I have found however that when I execute the Ant build file, the parameter user.dir is given the same directory as the project's directory (ProjectA). I thought this was a bit odd, and did some testing. I found that the user.dir parameter only changed if I changed the launch configuration so that the JRE was not running in the default launch directory. Then the user.dir changed. I suspect that behind the scenes the following is happening: 1.) The displayed users preference for the default launch directory is taken from the directory containing the build file. 2.) When the Ant build file is launched, it checks whether or not the user has chosen a directory other then the default launch directory. 3.a) If the user hasn't chosen a directory other then the default listed in step 1, it uses the user.dir parameter as the default directory. 3.b) If the user has chosen a directory othe rthen the default listed in step 1, the launch uses this other directory. I believe it is step 3.a which is incorrect. I should be choosing the directory containing the build file (ProjectA/build), rather then the current value for user.dir system preference (ProjectA). Hope you guys can fix it, I'm not sure if this is something new, but i'm sure I've never had this problem before. Dave
88186: Currently, there is no way to dynamically determine whether a particular portion of a feature (such as a non-plugin <data> element is really needed before it is downloaded). The only way to conditionally filter the download of <plugins> <included> features and <data> elements is with static filtering attributes (os, ws, arch & nl). Here is the usecase I am thinking of: A feature is intended to provide integration with an external application elsewhere on the system. It is possible to discover the external application by looking in standard OS meta-information locations (i.e. a file in /etc or ~/etc on linux or in the Win32 Registry on windows). If the application is not already installed, then it is desireable for the feature to bring it down as a <data> element and install it. However, if the application is already installed, then this would be an unnecessary download and should not done. The current way that feature InstallHandlers work is that <data> elements are actually downloaded automatically before the nonPluginDataDownloaded() method is invoked. This is too late to save the cost of the download. I propose that syntax and methods be added to the feature.xml and installhandler api to support dynamically filtering whether an element needs to be downloaded. This should be applicable to included features and plugins, as well as data elements. One possible syntax would be to add an optional 'filter = "true" | "false" : <i>false</i>' attribute to the <plugin>, <include> and <data> elements. This would tell the update system that the element should first be passed through a 'filter()' callback on the InstallHandler and the element would only be downloaded and considered necessary for the feature resolution if the method returns true. If the method returns false, then the element is treated as optional. This would look like so: <feature ... > ... <data id="some/archive.zip" .... filter="true"/> </feature> For compatibility reasons, the 'filter' method could be treated as an optional method of the InstallHandler and invoked via reflection. If the filter attribute is used and the installhandler does not have this method, then the filter result should be assumed to be 'true' (i.e. it is downloaded). This is consistent with parsing the feature.xml with a system that does not understand this attribute and hence ignores it. On the other hand, when examining installed features in order to build the runtime configuration, elements marked with the 'filter' attribute should be considered 'optional' for the sake of deciding whether a feature is valid.

115731: WorkingCopyPreferences.removeNode() does this: //... removed = true; String[] keys = keys(); WorkingCopyPreferences.keys() does this: checkRemoved() WorkingCopyPreferences.checkRemoved() does this: if (removed) { throw new IllegalStateException(message); Therefore, WorkingCopyPreferences.removeNode() always throws an exception. This is a problem because of Bug 111144, among other things. It would be nice to be able to remove a preference node. Suggested fix: in removeNode(), don't set removed=true until the work is complete. And/or, don't call checkRemoved() all over the place.

94852: Build id: I20050510-0010 Give focus to a view menu button. For example, in the Package Explorer view, give focus to the tree, and type shift+tab, shift+tab. The view menu (little down-pointing triangle) button should have focus (it looks a bit raised). When this button (or any button) has focus, screen readers will give a hint to their users that they can activate this button by pressing space. Space does nothing when pressed in this button. It should drop down the view menu. I realize that pressing Ctrl+F10 does drop down the menu, therefore typing space is not technically needed for accessibility, however it is really strange that here is a button (in a toolbar) that does nothing when "pressed" using the keyboard space key. For consistency, and to do the expected thing when used with a screen reader, we should allow space key to work here. (Note that all of our other toolbar buttons do activate when they have focus and space is pressed - including the very similar "Open Perspective" menu toolbar button).

115722: Both project locations and linked resource locations are stored on disk. Previously, they were stored as a string (Path.toPortableString,fromPortableString), but now they are arbitrary URIs. We need backward compatibility code to ensure we can read old and new locations, along with tests to ensure that old locations can still be read (ModelObjectReaderWriterTest already does this).
82868: Currnetly when selecting a default working set or adding breakpoints to a working set, the generic working set dialog is used which provides access to all kinds of workings sets. We should provide a custom dialog that only allows breakpoint working sets to be created/selected.
82869: The breakpoints view shows all sorts of working sets. The user may only want to see breakpoint working sets, so we should allow to filter non-breakpoint working sets.
82875: While stepping through external targets the file that contains the target should be opened so that the user can see what is being stepped through. Test case: The <import> is highlighted when stepping through the external target build.xml ====== <project default="foo"> <import file="extern.xml"/> <target name="foo" depends="externSubTask"> <echo>foo</echo> </target> <target name="internalSubTask"> <!--BREAKPOINT ON NEXT LINE--> <echo>I am internal</echo> </target> </project> extern.xml ======= <project name="none"> <target name="externSubTask" depends="internalSubTask"> <echo>I am external</echo> </target> </project>

95296: If you export your project settings to an Ant build.xml it could happen that it silently overwrites an existing file. It should only overwrite a file without warning if it was created by the export filter previously. The check if a file was created by the export filter is too lazy: E.g. a file gets overwritten if it contains these lines: <!-- --> If a project has dependencies it could overwrite many files... Affecting lin in AntBuildfileExportPage.java: if (line.length() > 0 && warning.startsWith(line)) Correct is: if (line.indexOf(warning) != -1)
