104496: In org.eclipse.ui.WorkbenchPlugin.checkCommandLineLocale() there is a check for Hebrew platform "iw". According to the following javadoc in the Locale class, it has been changed to "he" (with backward compatibility for "iw"). We need to add "he" as one of the languages we check for in this method. http://www.ics.uci.edu/pub/ietf/http/related/iso639.txt
96672: Build: N20050524-0010 When -debug is enabled in this build, I see the "Startup complete" message appearing twice: Time to load bundles: 15 Reading registry cache: 16 Starting application: 1221 Startup complete: 6292ms Startup complete: 12646ms This is caused by Workbench.runStartupWithProgress, which calls endSplash() an extra time. This is the cue we use for the "startup complete" debug statement. Either the extra call to endSplash() should be removed or we should find some other way to determine when startup is complete. Boris: is this new code in workbench likely to be staying in 3.1?
75752: I was messing around with a PDE project (migrating to 3.1 among other things) and wanted to recreate the build.xml file. So, I backed up my build.xml file and deleted it. I right-clicked the plugin.xml file and selected "Create Ant Build File". In doing this, I got an error dialog that said "Unable to write script /home/ewies/project/build.xml". When I did "touch build.xml" to create a dummy file (to test permissions, or something), the command completed without an error, but the resulting build script was empty. After looking at the stack trace in the error log, I saw which plugin and dove into the CVS source. It ended up that I had the "custom" flag set in my build.properties file. I had some custom ant commands in my project and had forgotten that the flag was set. I deleted build.xml again and removed the flag and all worked fine. To make a long story short, I had to do some digging around to figure out what was wrong. A more verbose error message would be useful. There is already an error dialog for this specific failure mode (see the callstack below), it just needs to be more verbose -- something akin to "Could not open /path/build.xml while updating project with custom build enabled."? 84694: In the Java editor, Open Declaration navigates from a selected reference to its corresponding declaration, (even if it is in a different file). For Ant this would mean navigating: to property definitions from ${} references to path definitions from refid= to target definitions from depends=, antcall target=, etc to macros definitions from entity instances This kind of navigation would be a huge advantage in debugging and maintaining medium to large size projects.

84690: I20050202 (jdt-core from I20050207) CompletionProposal.getDeclarationSignature states that it may return null for some proposal types. However, from the description I assumed that it was guaranteed not to return null *if* the proposal was of kind METHOD_REF. For methods on array objects, the declaration is always null, however. It would make sense to return "Ljava.lang.Object;" since this is where all the methods are declared that an array has. For FIELD_REF proposals to the "length" field of an array, it would probably make sense to return the array type, although this is not as important for us as there is no javadoc associated with the field.

95379: Currently we can spec 1.1.1.qualifier in the manfiest for a plugin and than add qualifier=context in the build.properties. At build time the context is computed as either the CVS tag used to check out or the time at which teh plugin in being built. Builder need the ability to set the context explicitly. For example, this allows them to have all elements of a build stamped the same way. So for example, a build property like qualifier.context=Foo might make sense. Related to this, perhaps we can treat qualifier=context in the plugin build.properties as a default. that is, if a plugin/feature has .qualifier at the end of its version number, assume that the qualifier=context and don't require the developer to set that property in the build.properties.

95371: The OrderedLock::doAcquire() function is not synchronized (like doRelease() or enqueue(...) for example) The problem with this is that the doAcquire() function can end-up removing a semaphore from the operations Queue without synchronizing this change with other thread that is in the middle of calling enqueue() to add a semaphore to the operations Queue. This could lead to the operations Queue being corrupted.

I suggest adding a small piece of code to the startup code that will check that explicitly, something like this: String jvmVer = System.getProperty("java.vm.version"); String minVer = "1.4.2"; if(jvmVer.compareTo(minVer) < 0) { System.err.println("JVM version (" + jvmVer + ") must be >= " + minVer); Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit().beep(); GUIApi.showError(this, "JVM version (" + jvmVer + ") must be >= " + minVer + " , exiting..."); System.exit(0); }

99729: This is related to bug #82641. With the new preference "Insert new line after annotations" set to true the behavior when adding a new Annotation is different based on whether the field has access modifiers. If the field does not have any access modifiers then the following behavior is seen when adding an Annotation ast node to a field declaration Example: String foo; Add an annotation: @MyAnnotation String foo; Add second annotation: @MyAnnotation @AnotherAnnotation String foo; If an access modifier exists then the code looks like this after the 2nd annotation is added. @MyAnnotation @AnotherAnnotation public String foo; Behavior should be the same whether the declaration has access modifiers or not.
96698: If you call getJavaElement() on a VariableDeclarationFragment which is part of a VariableDeclarationExpression you'll get a ClassCastException. In org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.VariableBinding.getUnresolvedJavaElement "VariableDeclarationStatement statement = (VariableDeclarationStatement) localVar.getParent();" is a useless and a bad cast because localVar.getParent() could be a VariableDeclarationExpression. For example in "For(int i=0;..." "int i=0" is a VariableDeclarationExpression "i=0" is a VariableDeclarationFragment If you do "i=0".resolveBinding().getJavaElement(), you'll get a ClassCastException.
99723: 3.1 RC2 The "Fast View" toggle in the fast view bar is always enabled, even if the view is non-moveable. It should be hidden or disabled if the view is non-moveable. See also bug 88345.

83385: The Event Details Dialog accessible via double click on a log message from PDE Runtime-> Error Log View has a layout problem when displaying long (multi line) message texts. The message text area grabs the full space of the dialog and is cut of failing to establish a scrollbar. The âException Stack Traceâ?and âSession Dataâ?become unreachable. Iâm not so familiar with SWT layout, but setting some heightHint to the GridData assigned to the msgText control in EventDetailsDialog.createTextSection (â? seems to be a quick fix for the problem. But maybe you can think of introducing a sash pane to make the message text area resizable, since I canât see a reason to restrict the message text length in a logged Status.
86410: The code formatter acts a little silly in the following situation: 1) You have "braces->class declaration" set to "next line" 2) You have "white space->parameterized types->type parameters->after closing angle bracket" set The intent here, of course, is that the whitespace after the angle bracket be a newline. However, the formatter generates something like: public class BoxOfComponents<C extends Component> { // ... } It apparently adds the newline from setting 1) then sees whether it ought to add a space as per setting 2). Setting it to do these in the reverse order or not add a space if there's already a newline would fix the problem.

75786: 3.1 M2 from bug 44961: My brace style in the code formatter is set to the 'Whitesmiths' style which indents curly braces to the level of the code that they surround. Like so: if (condition) { // do something! } In Eclipse 3.0.1, when typing the braces for the 'if' the braces would appear indented as above. But in Eclipse 3.1M2, the braces always move back to the level of the 'if'. Like so: if (condition) { // do something! } I've noticed that the same thing happens for for loops while loops, else blocks, try blocks, catch blocks, and switch blocks (although the try, catch and switch blocks weren't working in 3.0.1). I know that my formatting settings are correct because everything looks fine when I invoke the code formatter.

98423: The Find Unused Dependencies functionality should deem a dependency as used only if the plugin references java code from it. Right now, even if a plugin only uses an extension point from a dependency, PDE considers it a legitimate dependency.
95394: When I tried to resolve the type for "+=", I get null back, which is not what previous versions did. It also seems to return null in org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.DefaultBindingResolver:509. I've included a plugin to scan the workspace for Java comp units and resolve all the types on Expressions.
94060: some of the dialogs that say something like... Continue with "Undo blort"? have an ampersand in the Undo. The menu commands should not be used in text since there may be mnemonics assigned.
87777: xy/Try.java: package xy; public class Try { void hello() { C.world(); } } xy/C.java: package xy; class C { public static void world() { System.out.println("x"); } } Create two isolated ASTs. Compare the normalized binding of C#world with the one from the invocation C.world() in Try#hello returns false using isEqualTo. I normalized both binding first by calling getMethodDeclaration. The reason for the mismatch is that the type bindings for the declaring types have different modifiers.
87775: This bug is an umbrella for gathering solutions to integrating various third party libraries (e.g., hibernate, log4j, prevayler, ...) into Eclipse. Various of these use the context classloader or reflection to load classes. These are sometimes at odds with the Eclipse/OSGi component model's desire to structure classloading. While there are typically ways around the issues, they are sometimes not obvious to newcomers and so represent a barrier to adoption. Further, in the 3.1 timeframe we are actively looking at ways for the runtime to make life easier. Please attach your comments, directions and code snippets to this bug. The runtime team will correlate them and add them the RCP website (http://eclipse.org/rcp). Thanks

75793: I haven't been able to track it down if it's there somewhere at least, but there doesn't appear to be a way to remove a file from a commit set. I accidentally stuck a file in a commit set during a block select and I can't undo it. Not a big deal ultimately, just a little annoying if you know you are going to have a several commit sets before you commit, you have to remember to not commit that one file under the commit set's commit message.
85101: There have been numerous bug reports about slow update site searching and networking problems. The wizard should be redesigned so searches are done in the background. See bug 84592 for some comments.
87765: On starting with -debug the following is reported in the console Configuration file: file:/d:/i0222/eclipse/configuration/config.ini loaded Configuration location: file:/d:/i0222/eclipse/configuration/ Configuration file: file:/d:/i0222/eclipse/configuration/config.ini loaded Notice that the same config.ini is reported as being loaded twice. In the past great care was taken to avoid this situation. I suspect that recent changes in the launcher reintroduced this case.
111633: In the ILaunchConfiguration, the getWorkingCopy() method makes a working copy of a launch configuration. That part is clear. However, an ILaunchConfigurationWorkingCopy is also an ILaunchConfiguration, meaning that one could make a copy of a working copy. What is the expected behaviour if a doSave() is performed on the second working copy? Is it save the first working copy, or is it saving the original launch configuration, or both?

84603: Please add the ability to set the default width/size of the perspective bar. This is necessary when you've used the dock on top right preference and particularly when you've preloaded the perspective bar (ala Bug 84226).
79255: The following enhancements are to be made to the Memory View: * Memory View consists of multiple panes. (MemoryViewPane and RenderingViewPane). These view panes are statically managed the Memory View. As a result, new view panes cannot be added to the view easily. Planned Changes: Make Memory View more dynamic. It should be able to handle new view panes on the fly. * Memory View cannot host more than one rendering view pane. If there are multiple rendering view panes in the memory view, the behaviour of adding/removing rendering becomes confusing for user. All view panes listen to events from memory rendering manager. When a memory rendering is added, all view panes get the same event and will add the same rendering. As a result, the renderings are duplicated in the view panes. Planned Changes: Remove IMemroyRenderingListener and the add/remove rendering event mechanism from the memory rendering manager. The rendering manager is responsible for parsing memoryRenderingTypes extension only. A rendering view pane is responsible for managing the life cycle of its memory renderings. * Enhance IMultipaneMemoryView and IMemoryViewPane API. Planned Changes: These definitions of these two interfaces need to be refined. * Need IRenderingViewPane interface to allow actions to add renderings to a rendering view pane.
84605: We added support for colors and fonts in debug model presentations in bug 76514, but we didn't add the relevant javadoc to IDebugModelPresentation.
85933: Using HEAD, the following code doesn't compile. The parser is losing the Exception type parameters for the M type. public class X { public static void main(String argv[]) { new X().new M<Exception>(null) { void run() { Exception e = ex; System.out.println("SUCCESS"); } }.run(); } class M<E extends Throwable> { E ex; M(E ex) { this.ex = ex; } } }
84604: The Merge abd Keyword mode actions should be contributed to ResourceMapping but require a bit of modification before this can be done.

Clicking Finish will import from the selected zip file.
97906: Two versions of singleton fragments with the same symbolic name can be resolved at the same time. The resolver is not properly handling singleton fragments.
97901: While you cannot move a non-closeable view, you can still move its tab group. This allows the view to be moved, you can drop it on a different tab group or detach it.
94879: build I20050509-2010 - select a file in the Navigator and choose Properties - after looking at the properties, press Esc to dismiss the dialog - instead of dismissing the dialog, it clears the filter field - pressing Esc again dismisses it Same problem in the preferences dialog. This is unexpected behaviour. Esc is not normally used to clear a field. Esc within a dialog should dismiss it. Suggest not intercepting Esc, and just allowing backspace to clear the field (it's selected by default anyway).
92217: For consistancy and future developers not inheriting this code due to copy paste, all equals methods that do not try to aggressively exit should be updated. bad pattern: boolean equals = true; equals &= Util.equals(defined, someObject.defined); equals &= Util.equals(description, someObject.description); return equals; changed to: if (!Util.equals(defined, castedObject.defined)) return false; if (!Util.equals(description, castedObject.description)) return false; return true;

81563: I20041216-2000 JDIModelPresentation is using direct access to fDebugImageRegistry, which is lazily initialized via its accessor. Fixed in JDIModelPresentation.
82894: Debug to a breakpoint in an ant script, resume, then relaunch. Doesn't happen every time, but results in the target being suspended before any tasks get executed. Debug View claims the target is not suspended because it resume the target and it claims that it cannot retrieve stack frames for the thread because the thread is not suspend (even though it really is). the target's process is still alive and can only be killed at this point because the debug view is confused (as am I right now).
82895: The strings in the dialog for creating a new working set are broken. Looks like the changes to the .properties file are missing?
82891: Here is the scenario: Create a Java project, and add 2 jars, UseCalculator.jar and BaseProject.jar, to it. Then create another Java project, and a main java class, Test.java. Then add UseCalculator.jar to the build path of your 2nd java project. Once setup, perform the following steps: 1. Set a breakpoint at line 19 in Test.java; 2. Debug Test.java, when the breakpoint is hit, do "Step into Selection" on method addSomething(); 3. Source for CalculateSomething.class (contained UseCalculator.jar) is shown; 4. Do "Step into Selection" on method addSomething(); 5. Step into the Calculator.add(5,5); (will need to skip through the ClassLoader class a few times to get to the Calculator class) =>Result: Debugger Source Lookup dialog is open, cannot find com.test.Calculator which is contained in BaseProject.jar. Since the MANIFEST.MF file inside the UseCalculator.jar has its Class-Path pointing to BaseProject.jar, the VM classloader knows how to load the class in BaseProject.jar. The request is for JDT to be able to read the Manifest.mf file, and use the Class-Path info defined there to make up the source lookup path.

96605: Yesterday Olivier and I had a brief chat about the possibility to turnoff the verbose mode and set -log when running the eclipse build. We quickly tested that the .log files were being created, however we were not using the adapter, but directly the main class, which seems to have a slightly different behavior. Long story short, when I set verbose to false and set -log in the compilerarg I don't get any log file which is annoying.
92244: I20050419-1200 See also bug 92209. SelectedResourceManager is a selection listener and copies the entire text selection upon every selection change. This is very expensive if large amounts of an editor are selected and the selection changes fast, as when selecting witht the mouse or Shift+ARROW keys. It would be much better to lazily get the selection's content when it is requested via getSelectedText. To me it is even not obvious why SelectedResourceManager needs to be a (relatively expensive) Selection listener. It would seem enough to query the active resource and its selection upon request.

92241: 3.1 stream See bug 92209. Filling the clipboard with the current selection upon every selection change *really* hurts one test case: selecting big editor areas and changing the selection with the arrow keys and holding shift (or selecting large areas with the mouse). 83317: In a very large build environment, we had one developer move a feature from version 3.0.0 to 3.0.1 Unfortunately, there was a separate feature which had a "require" statement looking for version 3.0.0 The error messages are copied below. This was running the build in a headless mode from the command line. Because we had no mechanism to determine where the break occurred, and because the build is not tolerant of this sort of thing, our production development environment was down for three days. We need either a more robust build tool, or better diagnostic messages so we can diagnose and fix this sort of problem. Alternatively a "prescreen" step would be very useful. 80284: ================== Current Design ================== Currently, the Memory View is organized into two view panes. The Memory View Pane shows memory blocks as a hex renderings. The Rendering View displays a memory block in other formats. This design has a few drawbacks: * The presentation is not scalable. A memory block is represented by a hex rendering in the Memory View Pane. The view pane organizes memory blocks in tabs. When there exist many memory blocks, it is difficult to locate a memory block from the Memory View Pane. (User may not be able to see the entire tab label because there are too many tabs in the view.) * Navigation between the Memory View Pane and the Rendering View Pane is not intuitive. It's not easy to figure out the relationship between the hex rendering from the Memory View to the renderings being shown in the Rendering View Pane. * User is limited to see a hex rendering in combination with another rendering. User cannot choose other combination of renderings to be shown at the same time. ========= Proposal: ========= I propose to replace the Memory Monitors view pane with a tree viewer. The tree viewer shows all the memory blocks that are created for the current debug session. The viewer looks very much like the "Variables" view. In addition, the Memory View provides two rendering view panes. User can display any combination of renderings in these view panes. The Memory View now has three view panes, organized as follows: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Memory Block Tree Viewer|Rendering View Pane 1|Rendering View Pane 2 -------------------------------------------------------------------- As the user selects a different memory block from the tree viewer, the two rendering view panes will follow to show the renderings associated with the selected memory block. ============================= Impact to Debug Implementers: ============================= * To show a memory block in raw hex format, debug implementers must add the hex rendering in their memory block/rendering binding. * When a default rendering is created for a memory block, debug implementer has an option to decide where the default rendering is to be created. By default, the rendering is created in rendering view pane 1. However, by implementing IMemoryBlockPresention in the debug adapter's model presentation, debug adapter can direct the default rendering to be created in rendering view pane 2.

84637: Build: I20050202 ICommand now has API to configure what triggers a builder responds to (bug 60803). Various builders (external tools and CDT), already have similar mechanisms to avoid auto-builds. We need to make sure they have the necessary API to be able to migrate their builders to the new ICommand API. Possibilities: 1) Give builders a method to get access to their build command. Now that we support multiple builders with the same name, this isn't trivial for a client to do on their own. 2) Give builders API to get/set the build triggers in their command. This is a more limited form of 1) but achieves the same result.
102728: The addition of an N-ary operator could be a good improvement to prevent deep recursion. It could also simplify the code of the extended string literal. In this case we would preserve every part of the string literal concatenation and this would be an improvement for the ast conversion. Once this operator is in place, we should revisit bug 97220. A bit could be set on the string literal to prevent the warning from being generated and therefore it could simplify the filtering of those warnings depending on the context.

97939: 3.1RC1, WinXP The following scenario from the undo manual tests works properly: <detection of changed file> a. Open A.Java and B.java b. In A, click in the method name for "foo" and choose Refactor>Rename c. Rename "foo" to "foo2" d. In B, type some text anywhere. e. Go back to A and Select "Undo Rename method foo to foo2" from A's edit menu. f. Operation informs you that it cannot be completed since B has changed. g. Select OK h. Choose "Undo Typing" from A to revert the text part of the refactoring i. Go to B and choose "Undo Typing" to revert the typed changes followed by the text part of the refactoring change. However, if you first undo/redo the op in A before going to B (undo/redo the refactoring between steps (c) and (d)), the text changes from the failed refactoring are not placed in the undo stack. If there are text undo changes in A or B prior to the refactoring, they will now be invalid because the indices are off.

96649: The ConditionalPermissionAdmin spec has changed WRT to how Condition type objects are constructed: Previous version of the draft spec: 1) Using reflection, find a public static getInstance(Bundle, String ...) method on the Condition type class. 2) If a static getInstance method is not found then look for a public constructor that takes (Bundle, String ...) as parameters This has been changed to the following: 1) Using reflection, find a public static getCondition(Bundle, ConditionInfo) method on the Condition type class. 2) if a static getCondition method is not found then look for a public constructor that take (Bundle, ConditionInfo) as parameters.

92286: The purpose of the set* methods on EditorPart and WorkbenchPart is to ensure that clients correctly fire property changes when they're supposed to. EditorPart.setInput does not fire a PROP_INPUT property change. The property change is expected by clients, so most editors are failing to fire PROP_INPUT events. This causes all sorts of unpleasant side-effects (bug 92049). Changing this behavior now is a subtly breaking change, since the property change will sometimes be fired before the editor is in an internally consistent state (bug 90283). This PR requests the following: 1. Add JavaDoc to EditorPart.setInput to correctly describe the current behavior of setInput and what clients need to do to accomodate this behavior. 2. Add a replacement (setInputWithNotify) that behaves like setInput was originally intended to. 3. Deprecate EditorPart.setInput.
92283: Eclipse does not write a !SESSION header to the log file until there is something to log, causing the !SESSION timestamp to match the timestamp of the first item logged. This of course makes the first entry look like it happened on startup. It would be useful if Eclipse remembered when it started up so it could set the !SESSION timestamp accurately, allowing you to tell when the error occurred in relation to startup.

88364: Hi, Sun's javac (and that of other JVM providers) supports a few options that the Eclipse compiler does not: -O, -X, -J, -extdirs, and -sourcepath. Would it be feasible to add these to the Eclipse compiler? We (Fedora (and potentially other Linux distributions)) use the Eclipse compiler as our java compiler (ie. /usr/bin/javac is a script which basically just called the Eclipse compiler) but currently have to use a wrapper script to strip out the aforementioned options. It would be nice if we could call ecj directly. Any chance of those options being added? Other thoughts/comments? Thanks, Andrew
87033: FileManager should support operating in read-only mode. In this mode, it would be guaranteed that no changes to the file system would occur as consequence of calling the FileManager API. This would be useful when clients want to be able to *read* potentially existing data (FileManager is needed because it knows how to map between file names provided by clients and actual locations on disk) but do not want to cause any changes to the file system. See bug 85938 for an example of use case.

99005: This bug is being reported against Eclipse 3.1 RC1 build. EclipseStarter#makeRelative will fail at line #1051, if (base.getHost() == null ^ nonReferenceLocation.getHost() == null) on j9 2.2 where j2se (same installation dirs) will succeed. On j9, base.getHost()==null but nonReferenceLocation.getHost()=="". On J2SE 1.4.2, both return the value "". The problem seems to be that base.host is set from BasicLocation#setURL(URL, boolean) -> LocationManager#buildURL(String, boolean) where the URL return (line 50) is created from new File(String).toURL() which sets host to be null. However, in EclipseStarter#makeRelative(URL, URL), nonReferenceLocation is built from new URL(String) which sets host to be "". It is interesting that this differes from J2SE to J9, I suspect maybe a j9 bug. Is it possible to make Eclipse 3.1 robust enough to handle this scenario? Either EclipseStarter#makeRelative(URL, URL) handle getHost() so that null and "" are equivalent. Or, have BasicLocation#setURL(URL, boolean) and EclipseStarter#makeRelative(URL, URL) build the URL the same way - either new URL(String) or new File(String).toURL()?? What do you think? Do you feel this is a j9 bug? If so, I'll also open the j9 bug.
109281: While tracking down a possible leak I were calling viewer.setInput(null) when viewer.getInput()!=null but that gave an assert exception because the ContentProvider had been nulled out in handleDisposed(). I suggest you also null out Input to keep the state consistent since the code actually call inputChanged as if input had been nulled out. protected void handleDispose(DisposeEvent event) { if (contentProvider != null) { contentProvider.inputChanged(this, getInput(), null); contentProvider.dispose(); contentProvider = null; input = null; // add this line for consistency } if (labelProvider != null) { labelProvider.removeListener(labelProviderListener); labelProvider.dispose(); labelProvider = null; } }

79401: 1) Create a simple project with a simple folder inside it. 2) In Windows Explorer, expand the project and select the folder in the left pane. 3) Back in the Navigator view, try to rename the project. -> Rename fails because it cannot rename because Windows won't let you delete a folder that is being viewed in Windows Explorer. This is expected. Platform core returns a MultiStatus of the following form: MultiStatus ("problems encountered moving resources") MultiStatus ("Copy successful, but problems occurred removing old resources") Status ("Could not delete: d:\eclipse\test2\simple") The UI Error dialog shows the following in the details area: Problems occurred renaming the selected resource. Problems encountered while moving resources. Copy successful, but problems occurred removing old resources Could not delete: d:\eclipse\test2\simple\abc. Copy successful, but problems occurred removing old resources Could not delete: d:\eclipse\test2\simple\abc. Notice that the child MultiStatus from core is displayed twice. The root of this duplication is WorkspaceAction.recordError: private void recordError(CoreException error) { if (errorStatus == null) errorStatus = new MultiStatus(IDEWorkbenchPlugin.IDE_WORKBENCH, IStatus.ERROR, getProblemsMessage(), error); errorStatus.merge(error.getStatus()); } Observe that it stores the CoreException in the MultiStatus, *and* adds the error's status as a child of the MultiStatus. The JFace ErrorDialog class, when presented with this MultiStatus, recursively prints all MultiStatus objects, and all statuses contained within CoreExceptions. Since this MultiStatus contains both the original MultiStatus and the CoreException that carried it, it will get printed twice. The suggested fix is to not include the CoreException in the MultiStatus in recordError: private void recordError(CoreException error) { if (errorStatus == null) errorStatus = new MultiStatus(IDEWorkbenchPlugin.IDE_WORKBENCH, IStatus.ERROR, getProblemsMessage(), null); errorStatus.merge(error.getStatus()); } I tested this fix, and it produced an error dialog containing: Problems occurred renaming the selected resource. Copy successful, but problems occurred removing old resources Could not delete: d:\eclipse\test2\simon\abc.

87057: I've been interested in the recent work on content types for a specific reason. I'd like to use Eclipse (+ EPIC) to do Perl development in my work environment. However, many of our source files - including > 1000 test scripts - do not have a file extension, and currently cannot be identified as Perl scripts. I had hoped that content-type determination would allow me to programmatically define a Perl script by its contents, and so started experimenting with the M5 core enhancements. However, as far as I can tell, content descripters are visited based on a matching file name/extension check first, and there doesn't seem to be any way to match no extension. Would it be worth adding an attribute to the content-type extension indicating that the content type may be appropriate for a file with no extension?

102626: The an activeWhen element for the org.eclipse.ui.handlers extension point is not read from the plugin.xml. The problem is that HandlerPersistence.readHandlersFromHandlersExtensionPoint method is passing the activeWhen element to the elementHandler.create method but the method is expecting the expression element. ( Which is the child of the activeWhen element) I think that the simple fix should be to change activeWhenExpression = elementHandler.create(converter,activeWhenElements[0]); to activeWhenExpression = elementHandler.create(converter,activeWhenElements[0].getChildren()[0]); Obviously you would perform some error checking first. The same problem applies to the activeWhenExpression in the same method. This problem makes filtering impossible for any Handlers. This prevents more defining more then one handler for the same commands with different expressions. All handlers considered to be default and none is assigned to the command.

Won't compile with a version earlier than 20050125-0800. * @author sue */ public class DeferredContentProviderTest extends ApplicationWindow { private static final int HEIGHT = 200; private static final int WIDTH = 400; private class MyTableLabelProvider implements ITableLabelProvider { public void addListener(ILabelProviderListener listener) {} public void dispose() {} public Image getColumnImage(Object element, int columnIndex) { return null; } public String getColumnText(Object element, int columnIndex) { return (String) element; } public boolean isLabelProperty(Object element, String property) { return false; } public void removeListener(ILabelProviderListener listener) {} } private class MyComparator implements Comparator { public int compare(Object o1, Object o2) { int i1 = Integer.parseInt(((String) o1).substring(8)); int i2 = Integer.parseInt(((String) o2).substring(8)); return i1-i2; } } private ITableLabelProvider labelProvider = new MyTableLabelProvider(); private IContentProvider contentProvider = new DeferredContentProvider(new MyComparator()); private SetModel model = new SetModel(); public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println( "To recreate the ArrayIndexOutOfBounds bug:
" + "- Press End to navigate to the end of the table
" + "- Scroll upwards with the arrow keys; the element at the top of the visible area will be blank
" + "- Press enter on the blank item to call viewer.setInput()
" + "- Behaviour happens intermittently; scroll up and try a different element if the first one
" + " doesn't immediately throw the exception."); new DeferredContentProviderTest().open(); } public DeferredContentProviderTest() { super(null); setBlockOnOpen(true); } protected void configureShell(Shell shell) { super.configureShell(shell); shell.setText("Virtual Table test program"); } protected Control createContents(Composite parent) { Table table = new Table(parent, SWT.VIRTUAL); TableColumn column = new TableColumn(table, SWT.NONE); column.setWidth(WIDTH); final TableViewer viewer = new TableViewer(table); viewer.setContentProvider(contentProvider); viewer.setLabelProvider(labelProvider); viewer.setInput(model); String[] string = new String[200]; for (int i=0; i<200; i++) { string[i] = "element#" + i; } model.addAll(string); table.addSelectionListener(new SelectionAdapter() { public void widgetDefaultSelected(SelectionEvent e) { System.out.println("calling viewer.setInput()"); viewer.setInput(model); } }); return table; } protected Point getInitialSize() { return new Point(WIDTH, HEIGHT); } }

101350: build N20050622 The code to fix bug 97783 introduced a reference to a constructor that does not exist in the JCL/Foundation profile: FileWriter(File, boolean). Should use FileWriter(File) instead. Without this change the View Error Log button in the Configuration Details dialog will fail when running on JCL/Foundation.
112005: In the new keys preference page, it will be possible to view commands grouped by contexts or categories, in a tree. It will also be possible to see icons associated with commands. Unfortunately, this leads to a jarring piece of whitespace beside the category/context, as they do not have an icon. It would be nice to have a generic icon for a group of commands. When the user sees this icon, they are attempting to configure their key bindings (aka keyboard shortcuts) -- though it could be used in other areas in the future. A command is something that a key binding can trigger (like cut, copy and paste). This icon should be "mute" (i.e., not particularly eye-catching, but just space filling). For bonus points, there could be a separate icon for commands grouped by context, and commands grouped by category. A context is an application state, which generally (but not always) coincides with an editor. Examples are: editing text, editing java, debugging, etc. A category is simply a logical grouping of commands. Examples are: edit, file, text editing, navigate, etc. We have discussed unique icons for each category/context, but I feel this would lead to an interface that is too "cluttered". I'm not certain about this though.

Where it currently reads: "An error occurred synchronizing /org.eclipse.jdt.astview: Authentication error: com.jcraft.jsch.JSchException: Session.connect: java.net.SocketException: Operation timed out: connect:could be due to invalid address Authentication error: com.jcraft.jsch.JSchException: Session.connect: java.net.SocketException: Operation timed out: connect:could be due to invalid address", the second "Authentication error..." is redundant and makes it hard to parse the only interesting information (the project names).
88395: Compile the following two files: Color.java: ---------------------- package pack; enum Color {WHITE, BLACK} ---------------------- Test.java: package pack; import static pack.Color.*; public class Test { public static void main(String[] args) { Color c = BLACK; switch(c) { case BLACK: System.out.println("Black"); break; case WHITE: System.out.println("White"); break; } } } ----------------------------------------- Execute pack.Test and it will print out: Black as expected. Now reorder the two constants inside Color.java and recompile ONLY Color.java. Now execute pack.Test and it will print out: White This violates 13.4.26 of JLS V3 The problem is that the generated switch depends on the ordinal value from the enum. javac creates a translation table from compile time ordinal-> run time ordinal and switches based on the translated value.

87096: The property osgi.parentClassloader can be used to specify what the parent classloader should be for the bundle classloaders in the framework. This same property should be used by startup to set the parent classloader of the framework as well. This way the framework and the bundle classloaders will have a consistent parent to delegate to. This become more important in OSGi R4 when we need the ability for the framework to export packages that come from the parent classloader. The following values are available to specify the parent: fwk - indicates the framework classloader should be the parent app - indicates the application classloader should be the parent ext - indicates the extension classloader should be the parent boot - indicates the boot classloader should be the parent The default is boot. If this property is set the StartupClassLoader should use the following as its parent classloader fwk - use null, or the boot classloader app - use the application classloader ext - use the extension classloader boot - use null, or the boot classloader I will attach a patch to Main ...

I was then prompted twice. The first time said something about "Keyboard interactive" and requested a password. I entered my password. The scond one said something like "Enter keyboard interactive" and my options were OK and Cancel. I click OK and everything proceeded. 84824: Currently we only save the workbench preference store when we close the preferences dialog. 92428: If I use pde.build to generate my build scripts, the generated scripts will fail if my basedir has a space in the path. The culprits are the calls in assemble.<element>.<config>.xml to exec tar and rm and zip. The arg line needs to be quoted properly but is not. Changes are required to at least AssembleConfigScriptGenerator.generateTarTarget, generateGZipTarget, createZipRootFileCommand, and createZipExecCommand. (these three were sufficient in my use case). The correct output should be as follows (note the use of the single quotes): <exec executable="tar" dir="${assemblyTempDir}"> <arg line="-cvf ${tarargs} '${archiveFullPath}' ${archivePrefix} "/> </exec> <exec executable="rm"> <arg line="-rf"/> <arg line="'${assemblyTempDir}'"/> </exec> and so on. Following is a patch to correct the problem. "); //$NON-NLS-1$ //$NON-NLS-2$ //$NON-NLS-3$ + parameters.add("-r -q ${zipargs} '" + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ARCHIVE_FULLPATH) + "' . "); //$NON-NLS-1$ //$NON-NLS-2$ //$NON-NLS-3$ script.printExecTask("zip", getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ECLIPSE_BASE) + '/' + configInfo.toStringReplacingAny(".", ANY_STRING), parameters, null); //$NON-NLS-1$ //$NON-NLS-2$ //$NON-NLS-3$ //$NON-NLS-4$ } private void createZipExecCommand(List parameters) { - parameters.add(0, "-r -q " + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ZIP_ARGS) + ' ' + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ARCHIVE_FULLPATH)); //$NON-NLS-1$ + parameters.add(0, "-r -q " + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ZIP_ARGS) + " '" + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ARCHIVE_FULLPATH) + "'"); //$NON-NLS-1$ //$NON-NLS-2$ //$NON-NLS-3$ script.printExecTask("zip", getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ASSEMBLY_TMP), parameters, null); 87089: If you compare the versions 1.26 and 1.25 of the method doUpdateItem(Item item, Object element) in org.eclipse.jface.viewers.TreeViewer, you will notice a change in the way the image of the element is calculated. In 1.25, the image of the Element is set in the "buildLabel" method which doesn't have a special treatment for ITableLabelProvider. In 1.26, if the label provider is a ITableLabelProvider, instead of calling ILabelProvider.getImage(Object), the code always invokes ITableLabelProvider.getColunmImage(Object). This change has broken the icons on one of the EMF generated editors (the mapping editor) as the images I will attach here demostrate.

104416: When Bug 23064 and Bug 78799 were fixed, the Capture Output checkbox was removed. However, the Common tab is not visible from at least one more place, i.e., in the dialog for a Java project: Properties, Builders, an Ant Build. (True, Common tab is there for Run, External Tools... from the main menu.) To reproduce, create a Java project. Select Project, Properties, Builders. Click on New... button, select an Ant Build external tool. Give it a name. Click OK. The Main tab no longer has Capture Output (fine). But, there is no Common tab after Build Options tab, which is the new place to control capturing the output.
97229: RC1 Open several editor and leave some dirty. Close all. The 'Save resources' dialog is not not resizable. I think it is always better to make dialogs resizable as this makes it easier for users with diffent font sizes or using very long names. -> make the ListSelectionDialog by default
97220: 3.1 RC1 In the following case, we issue a 'Non-externalized string literal' warning for "deprecation": @SuppressWarnings("deprecation") public class X { } However this is always a constant (and will never be externalized). We should not issue a 'Non-externalized string literal' warning here (and for any annotation in general).
89609: In the Packages Explorer, if you have working sets turned on, syncing on a working set creates a resource scope on the contained projects. It could create a working set scope on the working set by using an instanceof check on the model object of the resource mapping. This should only be done if the selection contains one item.
89608: I20050330-0500 Import org.eclipse.platform as a binary feature Try to export it, you'll get an error indicating that the feature does not have a build.xml. To solve that you can either wrap the binary feature into another one, or when you know it is a binary feature you skip the build.xml step and directly call the package script.
94192: We added a number of performance tools to the builds, which should be removed or disabled by the time we release: - .options file in Eclipse install directory for perf stats - Performance view - Heap info status line entry

114683: From time to time we need to refactor plugins and move extension points. Since extension points derive their identity from that of their containing plugin, moving implies a rename. The old ext pt must be left behind for compatibility and the accessing code updated to read both the old and new ext pts when looking for extensions. Having done this, it would be nice to be able to deprecate the old extension point definition and give developers a chance to update their extensions to use the new extension point. The deprecation indication could go in the schema though it is unclear that this is shipped in the runtime builds of plugins. Alternatively it could be an additional attribute on the extension point markup itself. In either case, PDE UI would be updated ot have this notion and add the appropriate error/warning markers in the plugin.xml files. Of course, quick fixes would be optimal. :-)

88322: We want to add a pre-apply listener for the IPreferenceService#apply method. This will allow any registered listeners to modify the incoming tree before it is applied to the real tree in the workspace. We will look at modifying the project preferences so when they are loaded from CVS then they use the #apply method and the listeners can also take advantage of this. So it would look like: - read file from disk - call the listeners with the tree that is about to be applied - listeners can modify this tree - apply the new tree to the workspace Perhaps have the listeners registered via an extension point? Also, "listener" is an over-used term and it should be named something else. One recommendation is "interceptor".

108813: Well, not literally forever, but way way too long -- users will have to "end process" and start over. Bug 108806 is the most recent one opened against us in WTP, but have seen before for less extreme examples. I'm opening this bug to determine what improvements can be made at SWT level. I've marked as major since bug 108806 was marked as major by user-client. For the case described in bug 108806, I've noticed that for the 500K character line, we produce about 100K "styles" passed back to StyledText via LineStyleEvent. One thing I noticed, for example, is that a loop in DisplayRenderer goes through each style, eventually calling TextLayout.setStyle. There, is some code in there which is creating a (new) array of TextStyles, and it grows the array one item at a time, ending up using 100K System.arraycopies to grow the array "as they come in one by one". I did not test, but seems there might be ways to anticipate the size of this array and avoid all those array copies? So, first question ... why is it even requested of us to provide "all StyleRanges" for the line, when they are not all visible, obviously. Could some short cut be made there? Second question, do you think these "DisplayRendering" methods could be made more efficient, to at least allow user to limp along, or would problems just be encountered further along, such as is they try to type. Third question, any advice on how to proceed?

91994: Build: I20050419-1200 When problems occur parsing commands, you get entries in the log like the ones below. The first entry is an ERROR severity, and repeats the same information as the second entry, which is a warning. This duplication occurs because CommandPersistence#readCategoriesFromCommandsExtensionPoint calls the convenience method WorkbenchPlugin.log(String, IStatus), which creates a separate status object for the provided message. In this case the message is identical to the status, so WorkbenchPlugin.log(IStatus) should be used instead to avoid the duplication. !ENTRY org.eclipse.ui 4 4 2005-04-19 16:51:09.442 !MESSAGE Warnings while parsing the commands from the 'org.eclipse.ui.commands' and 'org.eclipse.ui.actionDefinitions' extension points. !ENTRY org.eclipse.ui 1 0 2005-04-19 16:51:09.473 !MESSAGE Warnings while parsing the commands from the 'org.eclipse.ui.commands' and 'org.eclipse.ui.actionDefinitions' extension points. !SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.ui 1 0 2005-04-19 16:51:09.473 !MESSAGE Commands should really have a category, not categoryId='': plug-in='org.eclipse.ui.tests', commandId='org.eclipse.ui.tests.commands.categoryLessCommand'.

105697: The 3.1 OperationHistoryEvent API includes notification of OPERATION_NOT_OK which is sent whenever an operation does not complete with OK status. However, with this API, a client cannot distinguish between an operation that was cancelled and an operation that had some other non-OK status. This is problematic for the action handlers which prune the history whenever a non-OK operation occurs. The history should not be pruned when the user cancels an undo, and the action handlers must be able to tell the difference. See bug #101215 for a particular instance of this problem. It is reasonable that an observer who did not originate the undo or redo would want to decide whether to prune the history on a non-OK operation attempt. In 3.1, the status is only returned to the caller.
98503: Excellent feature btw! When comparing nontrivial zip archives(e.g 5000 files & 20 Mbyte), the GUI will appear to be hung. I believe the problem is that work is being done synchronously on the user interface thread that really should be done in a worker thread. The progress view should probably display progress as well. 95476: 3.1M7 When PDE asks StateHelper to return all the packages visible to a particular bundle, the result includes all the system packages when the jre profile is set on the state. This problematic for PDE and JDT because the 100+ system packages are associated with the osgi plugin. So when PDE creates access rules for JDT to set on osgi.jar, every one of these system packages will have an associated access rule. These rules are totally unnecessary on osgi.jar since said JAR does not contain any of these packages. The only way PDE could help with system packages is if PDE had access over the JRE container, which we don't. Therefore, when PDE asks for visible packages, please exclude system packages.
95470: Build: 3.1 M7 When stepping in the debugger, I now see jobs flickering in the status line with names like "Debug Event Dispatch", and "Fetching children". These jobs should be system jobs because they are not directly initiated by the user, and if the user sees them it will likely just be confusing. Job.setSystem(true).

87856: You need code from HEAD (or upcoming I20050315-0800) to see the problem because before that point every opened editor was leaked (see bug 87796). The attached reference graph shows that the command manager holds on to a command which still holds on to handlers provided by the closed editor. I don't know the command code that well but it looks like a problem in the WorkbenchCommandManager: when a handler submission gets removed and there's no new handler for it's command ID then the command holds on to the old handler: removeHandlerSubmissionReal(...) removes the commandId from handlerSubmissionsByCommandId ==> handlersByCommandId in processHandlerSubmissions(...) will not contain the removed commandId ==> commandManagerWrapper.setHandlersByCommandId(handlersByCommandId) which is called in processHandlerSubmissions(...) will not reset the handler in the Command for the removed commandId
82168: The ant.home and ant.library.dir properties are not set for the parsing that occurs in the ant editor. Therefore any dereference of these properties will fail. 87852: ASTParser in 3.0 can be used in another standalone program to create Eclipse ASTs without actually running Eclipse. As the documentation says: char[] source = ...; ASTParser parser = ASTParser.newParser(AST.JLS2); // handles JLS2 (J2SE 1.4) parser.setSource(source); CompilationUnit result = (CompilationUnit) parser.createAST(null); But this doesn't work in 3.1 because ASTParser always gets the plugin object, and when it is null (in the case of a standalone program), a null pointer exception is raised. Please look at JavaCore.getOptions(). In 3.0, it tests if the result of getPlugin() is null; in 3.1, the test disappears, hence causing the problem.

82150: If you want to create a branch on an existing release TAG (the branch root), Eclipse always create again the given tag. It is possible to restrict TAG names on CVS so to protect important tags such as release tags. This 'bug' in Eclipse make it impossible to create a branch on a TAG you are not allowed to create. To do it : checkout a module on a TAG (MyFOOTag) and then, in the workspace, do a team --> Branch (MyFooBranch). If you go and look at CVS console, you will see that Eclipse set the tag MyFooTag again, which is wrong ! It should only create the branch tag on the release tag : tag -b -r MyFooTag MyFooBranch or simply tag -b MyFooBranch

107434: ReliableFile may throw a NumberFormatException when parsing the checksum into a long. This problem was discovered in the SMF version of reliable file and I verified that Eclipse has a similar problem. The proposed fix is to convert bytes to string using UTF-8.
94183: I20050509-1200, GTK+ 2.6.4, KDE 3.3.2, X.org 6.8.2, Linux 2.6.11 If you open the dynamic help dialog while a wizard is open, you are no longer able to type in the wizard. This happens because the dialog is automatically switched to a modal dialog by the following line in Shell.createHandle: if ((style & SWT.ON_TOP) == 0) modal |= (parent != null && (parent.style & bits) != 0); If this hack in SWT is removed, then you cannot click in the dynamic help dialog. Basically, GTK+ does not appear to support (at very first naive glance) typing anywhere but in the modal dialog, and it cannot handle two modal dialogs.

86565: I often find myself wanting to open all files that have outgoing changes via the synchronize view, but the view removes the Open action on multi-select. It's tedious to have to open them all by hand and supporting multi-select should be a trivial fix. I can give it a whirl if someone points me to the class.
107443: Currently, when creating a presentation, you can differ how views are presentation in only a few ways. Standalone vs regular views and within standalone, with or without a title. For many applications this is insufficient for branding or other reasons. I would like to see the ability to request the views be presented in a specific way. I see this as being implemented by the perspective by passing in some untyped object. The presentation API would interogate that object to determine how the view stack is created.

100806: If an "old style" OSGi R3 bundle uses unknown attributes in an Import-Package statement, then the State must not use these attributes as matching attributes in the new OSGi R4 resolver. For example: Import-Package; org.osgi.framework; specification="1.0" This example is likely a developer error because the -version is missing from the specification-version attribute. In OSGi R3 the "specification" attribute will be ignored by the framework and will not affect the resolution of the import. If an OSGi R3 bundle (i.e Bundle-ManifestVersion < 2) is installed then we should ignore all unknown attributes on Import-Package to prevent them from be interpreted as matching attributes.

108769: I was recently working out an issue with some code using the SWT FileDialog class. The soon-to-be-attached patch adds some additional information to the javadoc which explains some details I gleaned from reading the source but wasn't quite clear from the existing javadocs. The patch also adds a new method for setting the filter names and extensions which I believe is more convenient to use. I created the patch against the GTK version of SWT. It will need to be adapted for the other versions. (note: by "adapt" I merely mean that the line numbers need to be adjusted, none of the code is platform-specific)
96704: in org.eclipse.ui.internal.wizards.datatransfer TarLeveledStructureProvider.java and ZipLeveledStructureProvider use an essentially identical initialize() method. This method searches down into a directory until it finds a file (not a directory) and then adds that to Map children. Thus in a directory structure foo/bar/something/somethingelse/file.java The only entry will be an element with key "foo/bar/something/somethingelse/" and value "file.java" However in the case of a directory with no files inside foo/bar/something/somethingelse/ A file is never found, thus no entry of foo/bar/something/somethingelse/ is ever added to the Map children and this directory structure will never be imported. A possible fix is probably as simple as adding the element key="foo/bar/something/" value="somethingelse/" in the case that no file is found at the end.

121797: AbstractListViewer.internalRefresh(Object) does not wrap calls to setRedraw on its org.eclipse.swt.widgets.List within a try-finally block. There are many methods between the two calls to setRedraw that subclasses could throw Exceptions on which could cause setRedraw(true) not to be called. The most likely is the call to the LabelProvider through AbstractLabelViewer.getLabelProviderText(ILabelProvider, Object)
84723: The unknown file type prompting needs to be added to the Add to Version Control action
121796: AbstractListViewer.getControl() contains no javadoc, and is still declared abstract. It serves no purpose in this class. If it needs to remain, it should have javadoc to outline the requirement that an org.swt.widgets.List is expected.
84720: I20050202 (jdt-core from 20050207) - invoke content assist in the following locations (|) void method(List list) { Integer type= list.| int primitive= list.| } expected: proposals are ranked about the same in both locations actual: for the primitive, the List methods returning an int (indexOf, size, hashCode) are ranked high. For the Integer, the methods returning void (add...) are ranked the highest. I would support ranking autoboxing-proposals a little lower than direct matches, but autoboxing-proposals should still rank before the big mass (e.g. methods with a void return type).
121794: StructuredViewer.preservingSelection(Runnable) mentions calling the postUpdateHook method as its last operation, but no such method exists on StructuredViewer or any of its superclasses.
118153: 3.1.1 AbstractRulerActionDelegate.setActiveEditor(...) assumes that the given top-level editor part is a text editor and does not work if this is a multi-page editor. In order to support the mpe scenario we need to use an adapter here.

94995: Bundle URL objects must return paths that begin with '/' from the method URL#getPath. This applies to URL object which are returned from Bundle#getEntry and Bundle#getResource. This will not change the behavior of the URL only the string which is returned by URL#getPath.
93663: In Eclipse 3.0 we added a lot of new API to the org.eclipse.core.runtime.Platform class to allow for access to the new runtime. (OSGi) When this code was first released it was marked as experimental API and then just before the 3.0 release it was promoted to be real. During our API review for 3.1 we discovered that the PlatformAdmin class in OSGi was exposed as API on Platform#getPlatformAdmin. This was un-intentional and a missed reference during the last API review. (the javadoc still says "This is an early access API to the new OSGI-based Eclipse 3.0 Platform Runtime...") If the PlatformAdmin class is to be promoted to API, then it also exposes multiple internal classes that we do not want to be API. (the resolver, the state object factory, the state object, bundle descriptions, etc) That being said, we feel this method should be removed for Eclipse 3.1. As of build N20050504 there were 17 references to this method in the SDK. They are as follows: - 3 references to PlatformAdmin#getTimestamp - 2 references in Core Tools - 3 references in Ant to get the bundle descriptions to calculate classpaths (traversing bundle pre-reqs and accessing fragments) - 1 reference in runtime - 3 references in PDE/Build - 5 references in PDE/UI We propose the following: - remove Platform#getPlatformAdmin - add Platform#getStateTimestamp - make PDE and Ant "friends" and leverage the "buddy" mark-up in the bundle manifests so they can still use that class if necessary

83408: StyledText should allow hyperlinks to be specified. The links must become active (cursor changes, underlined, colour change) when the mouse is over the link or when the user tabs to the link. Links must be traversable by tabbing. There needs to be an event when the link is selected and when the link is activated (e.g. in IE the status bar shows detailed info about the link when the user hovers over it). The link should support a tooltip. Must be able to specify whether the link is always underlined or only when active.

106157: I20050803-0800, KDE 3.4.1, GTK+ 2.6.7, X.org 6.8.2 Linux 2.6.12 If you generate a job error while the preference dialog is open, then the error dialog opens parented to the workbench window. On kwin, this means the error dialog is on top, but you can only interact with the preference dialog. You must close the preference dialog before interacting with the job dialog. My favourite way to do this at the moment is to throw a NPE in the PatternFilter.
107488: 1. Run debug session 2. Create a second memory view 3. Add one memory block in one view and add a table rendering. 4. Add a second memory block in the second view and add another table rendering in another view. 5. Step the program. Notice that the rendering from the first view stops updating after the a step. The rendering was incorrectly set as hidden under pinned mode. To work around problem, choose another memory block or switch to another rendering and bring the rendering to the top again.

80373: Using Eclipse 3.1 11/24/2004 Nightly build (using Java 1.5 to run eclipse, but the same behavior is exhibited using other JRE's - the behavior is definately by design) I am debugging a client/server java app (both client and server running in debug sessions) in the same eclipse instance. I pin the console tab in the Debug Perspective to keep the Server console as the displayed console. If I stop/terminate the Server debug session, the Server console is removed (as expected) and the pin button is deactivated. Removing the pin, to me, is unexpected behavior. I would expect to see the next console (the Client) and have that console is pinned. Now when I restart the Server debug session, not only do I have to choose the correct console, but I have to reapply the pin. It seems that any output to a console, will shift focus and cause the console receiving the output to display. This also is unexpected as default behavior. The only time the consoles should change automatically (when debugging), is when the debug session stops at a breakpoint. There does not seem to be any way to make consoles pinned by default. This might not be a big deal when doing standalone apps, but it really slows down logic tracing when debugging client/server apps (you are never sure where you are). I know the Debug Configuration title is displayed at the top of the console, but since it is in normal text on the frame background, it is really hard to quickly focus on. An alternate solution would be to support multiple console tabs (one for each debug session with the Configuration title as the tab text). For now I am forced to start separate eclipse instances to debug the client and the server, maybe is is just because my brain cannot switch context that quickly. Thanks Mike
96746: Intro design uses the same idea as the platform when it comes to enabling a given intro plugin on various nl locales. That is, an nl fragment is dropped and it has the delta needed to translate the corresponding plugin. The design of intro model is thatr content files are translated and then dropped in the nl fragment. This should be sufficient. Relative resources and styles are not broken with this design because all relative resources are resolved relative to the location of the defining content file. An $nl$ is appended to the begining of each relative resource to enable dropping content files in fragments without the need to copy there associated resources into the fragment with them. This is broken in the XHTML intro model. need to force an $nl$ resolve on each resource in the XHTML DOM. We do that already for configExtensions, but we need pages too.

96730: Found this hole while doing Manual Undo/Redo Test Scenarios: scenario 7 - <correct handling of operation failure inside LinearUndoViolationUserApprover> If an operation fails during a linear undo violation, it's possible that the triggering undo context gets flushed from the failing operation. If there are other operations of that context in the history, the action handlers will properly update as these operations get removed. However, if the only operations that have the undo context also have other contexts, there is nothing actually removed from the history, and the action handler won't get further notifications. This means that when the action handler gets the original notification of the failure, it needs to always update the action after the flush, rather than relying on subsequent notifications.

96766: In releases prior to 3.1M7, you could print log messages which acted as hyperlinks in the console. A useful feature for speedy development. In 3.1M7 the parsing of the line number has been changed to require a new line following the final ")". Example: public class Tst { public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception { System.out.println("Log: Tst.main(Tst.java:5) Some message"); System.out.println("Log: Tst.main(Tst.java:6)"); } } Run the above in Eclipse. In the console the 'Tst.java:6' hyperlink will work, but the 'Tst.java:5' hyperlink will give 'Hyperlink Error' with reason 'Unable to parse line number from hyperlink'. Fix would be to return the parsing to just need a terminating ")", rather than ")\n". This was the functionality in 3.1M6 and before.
